Brand Self Reported Sustainability Efforts

This page was created by me, Steven Isley. I used LangChain and generative AI to automate the process of finding, downloading, and summarizing the self reported sustainability efforts of the top 1,000 most famous US brands. For full details, see this Google Colab Notebook.

Brand Fame Popularity Summary

UPS

 99 77

Environmental protection

UPS has made significant strides in environmental protection, focusing on carbon reduction, alternative fuel usage, renewable energy, and reforestation. The company has committed to achieving 100% carbon neutrality by 2050, a goal that encompasses scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions. In pursuit of this, UPS has seen a 6.9% decrease in CO2e emissions across these scopes year over year. A cornerstone of their strategy is the investment in alternative fuels; UPS has added over 15,600 alternate fuel and advanced technology vehicles to its global fleet, including more than 1,000 electric and plug-in hybrid electric vehicles. This aligns with their target of 40% alternative fuel utilization in ground operations by 2025. In the last year, UPS purchased 162 million gallons of alternative fuels, accounting for 26.5% of their ground fuel usage. Additionally, UPS is working towards powering 25% of its facilities with renewable energy by 2025, with 8% of its total electricity already generated from renewable sources in 2022. The company has also planted 28 million trees since 2012, aiming for 50 million trees by 2030 to contribute to a greener planet.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

UPS has outlined commitments towards enhancing diversity and inclusion within its workforce. The company aims to achieve 30% women in full-time management positions globally and 40% ethnically diverse full-time management in the United States by 2025. This initiative is part of UPS's broader strategy to create a more inclusive and equitable workplace, reflecting the company's dedication to social sustainability and worker welfare.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications

    • Nothing found

  • Commitments

    • Achieve 100% carbon neutrality by 2050
    • 40% alternative fuel utilization in ground operations by 2025
    • Power 25% of facilities with renewable energy by 2025
    • Plant 50 million trees by 2030
    • 30% women in full-time management globally by 2025
    • 40% ethnically diverse full-time management in the United States by 2025

Ford

 99 62

Environmental protection

Ford is actively working towards a more sustainable future with a focus on environmental protection. The company has committed to achieving carbon neutrality by 2050, with an interim goal of carbon neutrality in Europe by 2035. This commitment encompasses Ford's vehicles, operations, and supply chain, which together account for approximately 95% of its carbon emissions. To reduce its carbon footprint, Ford is transitioning to renewable, carbon-free electricity for its manufacturing processes. As of 2022, more than 60% of the electricity used in Ford's global operations was carbon-free. Additionally, Ford is the first U.S. automaker to engage its global supply chain in the Manufacture 2030 initiative, aiming to assist suppliers in meeting their carbon reduction targets. The company has also joined the First Movers Coalition to support the commercialization of zero-carbon technologies. Ford's efforts extend to water conservation, aiming to save billions of gallons of water and working towards zero waste by incorporating sustainable materials into its vehicles.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Ford is committed to building a more inclusive and equitable society, which includes ensuring the welfare of its workers. The company has invested over $525 million to train the next generation of auto technicians, preparing the workforce and local communities for the transition to electric vehicles (EVs). Since 1949, Ford and the Ford Fund have invested more than $2.2 billion in initiatives aimed at providing access to essential services, building new skillsets, and opening pathways to high-quality jobs. Ford is also creating a culture of inclusion where team members are valued, respected, and empowered to bring their true selves to work. This approach is part of Ford's broader effort to transform its business and foster a just transition for its workforce.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Achieve carbon neutrality by 2050
    • Achieve carbon neutrality in Europe by 2035
    • Use 100% local, renewable electricity in all manufacturing by 2035
    • Reach true zero waste to landfill across operations
    • Eliminate single-use plastics from operations by 2030

Taco Bell

 99 67

Environmental protection

Taco Bell has implemented several initiatives to protect the environment and reduce its carbon footprint. The company transitioned all of its cold beverage cups and lids in U.S. restaurants to recyclable polypropylene, eliminating polystyrene and reducing resin usage. This change is part of Taco Bell's broader commitment to reducing landfill waste and greenhouse gas emissions. Additionally, Taco Bell has joined the NextGen Cup Consortium to support the development of recyclable hot cups. In terms of sustainable sourcing, Taco Bell uses palm oil in its Cinnabon DelightsÂ® that is certified by the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO), aiming to minimize the negative impact of palm oil production on the environment and communities. The company has also made strides in sustainable packaging, with paper bags made from 100% recyclable and sustainably sourced materials and a switch from polystyrene foam to polypropylene for side containers. Taco Bell has set goals for 2025 to make all customer-facing packaging recyclable, compostable, or reusable, remove PFAS, Phthalates, and BPA from all customer-facing packaging, and add recycling and/or composting bins to all restaurants where infrastructure permits.

In a significant move to improve the environmental effects of its supply chain, Taco Bell has partnered with Cargill and the National Fish and Wildlife Foundation (NFWF) to implement conservation and regenerative agriculture practices across cattle grazing lands. This $2 million partnership aims to conserve natural resources and reduce the climate impact of beef, one of Taco Bell's top-selling ingredients. The partnership will support beef producers with technical and financial tools to expand regenerative ranching practices, expected to sequester up to 44,000 metric tons of carbon dioxide equivalent per year by 2030.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO)
  • Commitments
    • Make all customer-facing packaging recyclable, compostable, or reusable by 2025
    • Remove PFAS, Phthalates, and BPA from all customer-facing packaging by 2025
    • Add recycling and/or composting bins to all restaurants, where infrastructure permits, by 2025

Amazon

 99 76

Environmental protection

Amazon is actively working on various fronts to protect the environment. The company has committed to reaching net-zero carbon emissions by 2040 and is on a path to power its operations with 100% renewable energy by 2025. This commitment extends to its transportation network, where Amazon has introduced the first-ever zero-emission capable cargo ship and is rolling out custom electric delivery vehicles from Rivian. In addition to its efforts in renewable energy and transportation, Amazon is innovating in packaging to reduce waste and increase recyclability, with a goal to make Amazon device packaging 100% recyclable by 2023. The company is also committed to water stewardship, aiming to make AWS water positive by 2030, and is engaged in conservation and restoration initiatives to protect natural resources. Amazon's scale and culture of innovation are leveraged to drive sustainability across five impact areas: Driving Climate Solutions, Reducing Packaging and Waste, Protecting Natural Resources, Advancing Human Rights, and Innovating Products and Services.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Amazon is committed to advancing human rights and ensuring that partners in its supply chain are treated with fundamental dignity and respect. The company's efforts in worker welfare are part of its broader sustainability and social responsibility initiatives. Amazon's approach includes a focus on the well-being of its employees, offering benefits, diversity, equity, inclusion programs, upskilling, and training opportunities. Additionally, Amazon has made significant investments in community impact programs such as STEM education, housing equity, help for hunger, and disaster relief and response, which indirectly support worker welfare by contributing to the overall well-being of the communities where its employees live and work.

sources: 1, 2

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Commitment to be net-zero carbon by 2040
    • On a path to powering operations with 100% renewable energy by 2025
    • Goal to make Amazon device packaging 100% recyclable by 2023
    • Commitment to make AWS water positive by 2030

McDonald's

 99 63

Environmental protection

McDonald's is actively engaged in various environmental protection initiatives focusing on climate action, sustainable packaging, and the preservation of natural resources. The company has submitted evolved science-based targets for validation by the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) to align with a 1.5Â°C pathway and the new FLAG framework. Projects executed between 2019 and 2023 are expected to contribute to a 33% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions from their global 2015 baseline. In terms of packaging and waste, McDonald's reports that approximately 81.0% of their primary guest packaging materials and 97.2% of their primary fiber packaging come from recycled or certified sources as of the end of 2022. They aim to drastically reduce plastics in Happy Meal toys and transition to more sustainable materials by the end of 2025, having already reduced virgin fossil fuel-based plastic in Happy Meal toys by 47.8% globally. Additionally, McDonald's is committed to supporting deforestation-free supply chains for its primary commodities, achieving 99.0% deforestation-free sourcing for beef, soy for chicken feed, palm oil, coffee, and fiber for guest packaging in 2022. The company has also joined the Consumer Goods Forumâs Forest Positive Coalition to address commodity-driven deforestation and climate change issues across the sector.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

McDonald's has implemented several policies aimed at promoting animal welfare across its supply chain. The company has committed to sourcing chickens not treated with antibiotics important to human medicine in the U.S. and has eliminated the use of Highest Priority Critically Important Antibiotics (HPCIAs) to human medicine from all chicken served in several countries, with plans for China to comply by the end of 2027. Additionally, McDonald's announced a policy in December 2018 to reduce the overall use of antibiotics important to human health in its beef supply chain, covering 10 beef sourcing markets around the world. The company is also on a journey to advance more sustainable beef production, striving to improve environmental practices, make a positive difference in the lives of farmers, and drive improvements in animal health and welfare. Furthermore, McDonald's has made a commitment to source only cage-free eggs by 2025 in the U.S. and Canada and is 60% towards achieving this goal. In terms of pork, more than 91% of the pork purchased in the U.S. comes from suppliers that have phased out the use of gestation stalls for housing confirmed pregnant sows, with a commitment to maximize the time that pregnant sows spend in a group environment. McDonald's has also announced a global commitment to source chickens raised with improved welfare outcomes, outlining eight Broiler Welfare Commitments expected to be fully implemented by the end of 2024 in 13 key markets.

sources: 1

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Submit evolved science-based targets for validation by SBTi in line with 1.5Â°C and the new FLAG framework.
    • Contribute to a 33% reduction in GHG emissions from the global 2015 baseline through projects executed between 2019â2023.
    • Drastically reduce plastics and offer sustainable Happy Meal toys and transition to more sustainable materials by the end of 2025.
    • Support deforestation-free supply chains for primary commodities (beef, soy for chicken feed, palm oil, coffee, and fiber for guest packaging) achieving 99.0% deforestation-free sourcing in 2022.
    • Source only cage-free eggs by 2025 in the U.S. and Canada.
    • Phase out the use of gestation stalls for housing confirmed pregnant sows in the U.S. by the end of 2024.
    • Fully implement eight Broiler Welfare Commitments by the end of 2024 in 13 key markets.

M&M's

 99 85

Environmental protection

M&M's has introduced a pilot project featuring compostable packaging for their Milk Chocolate and Peanut Chocolate Candy. This initiative is part of their broader sustainability mission to reduce waste and environmental impact. The compostable packaging is made primarily from plant-based materials, including a bio-plastic film that contains about 50% plant material and cellulose derived from high purity wood pulp. This packaging is designed to decompose in commercial composting facilities within 90 days, turning into compost used to grow new plants. M&M's efforts also include removing 98 tons of plastic from their Theater Boxes to make them 100% recyclable and incorporating 15% recycled content into their Club Jars for M&M's, STARBURST, and SKITTLES. These steps are part of Mars Incorporated's commitment to redesigning over 12,000 packaging types across its portfolio to contribute to a circular economy, with the ultimate goal of making 100% of its packaging reusable, recyclable, or compostable.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Biodegradable Products Institute (BPI) Certification
  • Commitments
    • 100% of packaging to be reusable, recyclable, or compostable

KFC

 99 67

Environmental protection

KFC is actively working towards reducing its environmental impact through various sustainability initiatives. The company has set ambitious goals to reduce its greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 46% by 2030 and aims to reach net-zero emissions globally by 2050. A key strategy in achieving these goals is the practice of circularity, which involves recycling, composting, or re-using products and resources to allow them to enter a new lifecycle or supply chain. KFC's development team has created Green Line Furniture, a collection made from recovered materials that are both durable and have a lower environmental impact. This furniture, which generates 32% less greenhouse gas emissions during transportation, will be incorporated into new and extensively remodeled restaurants across multiple markets. Additionally, in Australia, KFC is partnering with a supplier to use sustainable building materials made from hard-to-recycle waste, such as milk and juice cartons, in its restaurant construction. These initiatives are part of KFC's broader commitment to sustainable development and minimizing its environmental footprint as it continues to expand globally.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

KFC is committed to feeding people's potential and fighting inequality through various programs aimed at providing access to skill-building, opportunities, and food. The company's initiatives include Hack-A-Preneurs and Foster Children Mentoring, which are designed to strengthen equality and sustain communities. Additionally, KFC focuses on equity and inclusion to ensure that its workforce and the communities it serves have access to necessary resources and opportunities. These efforts are part of KFC's broader social impact strategy, which aims to support the welfare of its workers and contribute positively to the communities in which it operates.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

KFC has announced new chicken welfare metrics it will pursue worldwide, building on its existing industry-leading animal welfare guidelines. The company is committed to improving chicken welfare as part of its sustainability efforts. In addition, KFC has committed to transitioning to 100% cage-free eggs for all menu items and ingredients in the U.S. and Western Europe by the end of 2026 and globally by 2030. These commitments reflect KFC's dedication to promoting the health and welfare of the animals used in its products.

sources: 1

Transparency

  • Certifications

    • Nothing found

  • Commitments

    • Reduce GHG emissions by 46% by 2030
    • Reach net-zero emissions globally by 2050
    • Transition to 100% cage-free eggs in the U.S. and Western Europe by the end of 2026 and globally by 2030

Adidas

 99 72

Environmental protection

Adidas has committed to becoming a more sustainable company with a clear focus on environmental protection. Their roadmap for 2025 and beyond includes ambitious targets to reduce their environmental impact significantly. By 2025, Adidas aims for nine out of ten articles to be sustainable, defined by the use of environmentally preferred materials. They have committed to achieving climate neutrality across their entire value chain by 2050, with intermediate goals of a 15% reduction in GHG emissions per product by 2025 and a 30% reduction in absolute GHG emissions across their entire value chain by 2030, both measured against 2017 levels. Adidas is also focusing on more sustainable materials and circular services, aiming to replace all virgin polyester with recycled polyester by 2024, and has already achieved 96% recycled polyester usage in 2022. They have partnered with Parley for the Oceans since 2015, using Parley Ocean Plastic as a replacement for virgin polyester. Additionally, Adidas has committed to sourcing 100% of its cotton from more sustainable sources since the end of 2018 and is working on increasing the use of recycled and organic cotton. They are also focusing on responsibly sourced leather, with more than 99% of their leather volume audited in accordance with the Leather Working Group protocol. Furthermore, Adidas is exploring plant-based materials and has launched products designed for circularity, including footwear and apparel that can be completely recycled after use.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Adidas has set clear targets for 2025 to ensure worker welfare within their operations and supply chain. They aim to maintain a Lost-Time Incident Rate (LTIR) below the industry average, achieve zero fatal accidents, and zero Occupational Illness Frequency Rate (OIFR). In their supply chain, Adidas targets 90% of Tier 1 strategic suppliers to achieve at minimum 4S in social impact indicators, with 100% achieving 3S or better. They are also focusing on fair wages, aiming for progressive improvement in compensation measured by fair wage benchmarks across strategic Tier 1 suppliers. Additionally, Adidas is working towards achieving gender wage parity for workers and their supervisors in strategic Tier 1 suppliers. These efforts are part of a broader strategy to manage high-risk human rights issues across their value chain by 2025.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Adidas uses a small fraction of animal-derived materials, primarily leather, which constitutes approximately 3% of their total materials volume. They ensure that more than 99% of their leather volume is audited in accordance with the Leather Working Group (LWG) protocol, with most hides sourced from tanneries with the highest LWG rating (LWG Gold). Adidas is working with the LWG to broaden the scope of the audit to include traceability to the slaughterhouse by 2030, aiming for higher transparency on environmental impacts such as deforestation from the origin of the material.

sources: 2

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Leather Working Group (LWG) protocol
  • Commitments
    • By 2025, nine out of ten Adidas articles will be sustainable
    • By 2025, achieve a GHG emissions reduction of 15% per product
    • By 2025, achieve climate neutrality (GHG) at Adidas' own operations
    • By 2030, reduce absolute GHG emissions across the entire value chain by 30%
    • By 2050, Adidas will be climate neutral

Oreo Cookies

 98 80

Nothing found

Nintendo

 98 68

Environmental protection

Nintendo has implemented several initiatives to reduce its environmental impact and promote sustainability. The company established a Sustainability Committee in 2020, which has led to the purchase of 100% renewable energy for its offices and a suburban shipping facility. Additionally, Nintendo participates in a carbon-balance program that supports local reforestation projects to offset CO2 emissions from natural gas usage in its cafeterias and other areas. Nintendo of America offers a post-sales recycling program for electronics, providing postage and instructions for consumers to send video game products for R2-certified recycling. This initiative has prevented over 1 metric ton of materials from ending up in landfills in 2022 alone.

Nintendo's commitment to environmental protection extends to its product design, with efforts to comply with environmental laws in each country and reduce environmental burdens. The company focuses on eco-friendly design, energy-saving measures, and facilitating product recycling and overall waste reduction. For instance, Nintendo uses vegetable ink and non-VOC ink for game labels and hardware packaging, which are more environmentally friendly and facilitate recycling. The company also emphasizes green procurement, ensuring that component parts for video game systems and accessories do not contain toxic chemical substances and comply with internal chemical substance control standards.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • ISO 14001 certification
  • Commitments
    • 100% renewable energy usage for offices and suburban shipping facility
    • Participation in carbon-balance program for local reforestation projects
    • R2-certified recycling for post-sales electronics

Chick-fil-A

 98 61

Environmental protection

Chick-fil-A is actively engaged in various sustainability initiatives aimed at reducing its environmental impact. The company is committed to decreasing food waste and what is sent to landfills, exploring renewable energy options, and engaging employees, suppliers, and others in its sustainability journey. A significant part of its commitment is the goal to divert 25 million pounds of food waste from landfills by 2025 through programs such as the Chick-fil-A Shared TableÂ® program, composting, and other efforts. In 2022, Chick-fil-A diverted 13.9 million pounds of food waste from landfills through food donations and composting by its restaurants. Additionally, the company is exploring energy-saving opportunities, such as piloting a solar-powered microgrid system in its restaurants. At the Chick-fil-A Support Center in Atlanta, sustainability efforts focus on food waste, packaging waste, recycling, water consumption, and energy optimization. The Support Center is also working towards achieving zero-waste-to-landfill status and has already managed to divert nearly 10,000 pounds of waste from landfills through composting and recycling initiatives.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Divert 25 million pounds of food waste from landfills by 2025

PayPal

 98 67

Environmental protection

PayPal is actively engaged in various initiatives to protect the environment and mitigate climate change impacts. The company has committed to achieving net-zero greenhouse gas emissions across its value chain by 2040. To this end, PayPal has established science-based emissions reduction targets, which have been validated by the Science Based Targets initiative. These targets are aligned with limiting global temperature rise to no more than 1.5ËC. Since 2021, PayPal has sourced 100% of its global data center energy use from renewable generation. The company also prioritizes energy efficiency and renewable energy procurement across its global office locations. Additionally, PayPal engages with its largest vendors through the CDP Supply Chain to develop GHG inventories and learn about science-based targets. In terms of water management, PayPal maintains water efficiency standards across its fully managed office locations and has invested in technologies to monitor and reduce water consumption. The company has also implemented recycling programs and a zero-landfill strategy for electronic waste across its global offices. PayPal is a founding member of the Climate Innovation for Adaptation and Resilience (CIFAR) Alliance and supports the Catalyst Fund, which aids climate-vulnerable communities. The company's environmental efforts are reported transparently in line with the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) and other environmental reporting standards.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Achieving net-zero greenhouse gas emissions across its value chain by 2040
    • Sourcing 100% of global data center energy use from renewable generation since 2021

Google

 98 74

Environmental protection

Google is actively working towards environmental protection through various initiatives aimed at reducing carbon emissions, promoting renewable energy, and fostering a circular economy. The company is committed to achieving net-zero emissions across its operations and value chain by 2030, supported by its goal to operate its data centers and office campuses on 24/7 carbon-free energy, including solar and wind. Google's efforts extend to water stewardship, aiming to replenish 120% of the freshwater volume it consumes and improve water quality in communities where it operates. Additionally, Google is advancing a circular economy by maximizing the reuse of finite resources across its operations, products, and supply chains, and enabling others to do the same. The company's initiatives also include reducing plastic pollution and supporting the transition to clean energy for everyone. Google's Bay View campus in California exemplifies its commitment, being powered by wind, solar, and geothermal energy. Furthermore, Google has entered into power purchase agreements in Belgium and the Netherlands to operate on 24/7 carbon-free energy by 2030.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Committing to achieving net-zero emissions across operations and value chain by 2030.
    • Aiming to operate data centers and office campuses on 24/7 carbon-free energy by 2030.
    • Planning to replenish 120% of the freshwater volume consumed across offices and data centers.
    • Aiming to help individuals, cities, and partners collectively reduce 1 gigaton of carbon-equivalent emissions annually by 2030.

Lay's

 98 71

Environmental protection

Frito-Lay has demonstrated a strong commitment to environmental sustainability through various initiatives aimed at reducing its environmental impact. The company has made significant strides in harnessing renewable energy, such as switching its Modesto, CA plant to solar power and aiming to run its Casa Grande facility primarily on renewable energy and recycled water. Frito-Lay has also focused on sustainable agriculture, ensuring that 100% of the corn and potatoes used in its products in North America are sustainably sourced. The company has implemented a sustainable farming program and is working towards eliminating 1.4 million metric tons of greenhouse gases. In terms of water conservation, Frito-Lay has saved 31 million gallons of water by reducing water use intensity by 4.8% year over year. The company is also converting its fleet to all-electric vehicles and using 100% natural gas sourced from renewable resources for its fleet, significantly reducing its greenhouse gas emissions and fossil fuel consumption. Additionally, Frito-Lay has reduced its packaging plastic by more than 7.8 million lbs since 2019 and is investing in breakthrough packaging technology with the goal of being 100% recyclable, compostable, biodegradable, or reusable by 2025.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • LEED EB Gold for Casa Grande Facility
  • Commitments
    • Net water positive by 2030
    • 100% recyclable, compostable, biodegradable, or reusable packaging by 2025

Mac

 98 60

Environmental protection

MÂ·AÂ·C Cosmetics is actively working towards improving the sustainability of its packaging and reducing its environmental impact through initiatives such as the Back-To-MÂ·AÂ·C program. This program is part of their commitment to protect the planet. Additionally, MÂ·AÂ·C Cosmetics ensures that the electricity used to power their e-commerce data center in The Americas is covered by renewable energy certificates, highlighting their dedication to using renewable energy sources. The brand is also focused on creating products with safe, good-for-skin ingredients, and is transparent about the ingredients that are not included in their products, allowing consumers to make informed choices that align with their values towards environmental sustainability.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

MÂ·AÂ·C Cosmetics has demonstrated a commitment to supporting underserved communities through its VIVA GLAM campaign. Since 1994, the campaign has raised more than $500,000,000 in support of people and communities in need. The funds from the sale of VIVA GLAM Lipstick are directed towards organizations and programs aimed at creating healthy futures and equal rights for all, with a focus on the fight against HIV/AIDS, and supporting women and girls and the LGBTQIA+ community. This initiative reflects MÂ·AÂ·C's dedication to promoting acceptance, driving impact, and inspiring change towards a better future for underserved communities.

Old Navy

 98 64

Environmental protection

Old Navy is actively working towards more sustainable clothing production practices. They have set several environmental goals to reduce their impact. By the end of 2022, Old Navy aims for 100% of their cotton to be sourced from Better Cotton, verified US-grown, or recycled materials. They are also committed to eliminating plastic shopping bags by 2023 and implementing a hanger recycling program across all stores in the continental US & Canada by the end of 2023. Furthermore, the brand has pledged that 100% of its denim will be made using water-saving techniques by the end of 2022. Old Navy is also working towards making 85% of the fibers used in their clothing more sustainable by 2025 and plans to source 60% of their polyester from recycled materials by the same year. These initiatives highlight Old Navy's commitment to reducing plastic waste, conserving water, and increasing the sustainability of the materials used in their products.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Old Navy is committed to unlocking career potential through their This Way ONward program, which focuses on boosting confidence and providing career opportunities for young people, with a particular focus on serving Black and Latinx youth. The program offers one-on-one mentorship, coaching, and on-the-job skill building in partnership with non-profits like Boys & Girls Clubs. This initiative demonstrates Old Navy's commitment to supporting the welfare and development of its workers and the broader community by providing meaningful career opportunities and support.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

    • Nothing found
  • Commitments

    • No more plastic shopping bags by 2023
    • All stores in the continental US & Canada to participate in a hanger recycling program by the end of 2023
    • 100% of denim to be made with water-saving techniques by the end of 2022
    • 85% of the fibers used in clothing to be more sustainable by 2025
    • 60% of polyester to come from recycled sources by 2025

Papa John's

Gillette

 98 71

Environmental protection

Gillette is actively working towards reducing its environmental impact through various initiatives aimed at protecting the planet. The company has set ambitious goals to improve its environmental footprint by 2030, focusing on packaging, product waste, water conservation, manufacturing operations, and supply chain improvements. Gillette is striving to make all its packaging recyclable by 2030, with significant progress expected by 2023. It has also launched a razor recycling program in partnership with TerraCycle in the U.S. in 2019, aiming to expand this initiative globally. The company has achieved 'Zero Manufacturing Waste to Landfill' status across its global network of plants, a significant milestone in its sustainability journey. Additionally, Gillette has committed to reducing its energy use, aiming for 100% renewable purchased electricity by 2030 and a 50% reduction in greenhouse gas emissions for manufacturing. A 35% reduction in water consumption per production by 2030 is also part of its environmental goals. Gillette's efforts extend to product design, with refillable razors like Fusion and Mach3 designed for durability and less frequent replacement, and modernized razor blades that require less water for rinsing. The company is also exploring innovative solutions like the worldâs first waterless razors for 'assisted shaving,' Gillette TREO, to conserve water during the shaving process.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Achieve 100% recyclable packaging by 2030
    • Expand razor recycling program globally
    • Achieve 'Zero Manufacturing Waste to Landfill' status across all plants
    • Reduce energy use and achieve 100% renewable purchased electricity by 2030
    • Reduce greenhouse gas emissions for manufacturing by 50%
    • Achieve a 35% reduction in water consumption per production by 2030

Jif

 98 73

iPad

 98 63

Environmental protection

Apple has made significant strides in environmental protection, particularly with its iPad products. The company has committed to making all its products carbon neutral by 2030. This ambitious goal is being pursued through a variety of innovative strategies across the product lifecycle, from sourcing materials to manufacturing, shipping, and product use. A significant portion of the materials used in Apple products, including the iPad, now comes from recycled and renewable sources. In 2022, 20% of all material shipped in Apple products was from these sustainable sources. Apple has also engaged over 300 suppliers, representing more than 90% of its direct manufacturing spend, to commit to using 100% renewable electricity for all Apple production by the same target year. The company has achieved an 80% reduction in shipping emissions for the HomePod (2nd generation) through its transportation plan and has seen over a 70% reduction in average product energy use since 2008. Additionally, Apple directed more than 40,000 metric tons of electronic scrap to recycling in 2022, further emphasizing its commitment to environmental sustainability. Apple's approach to carbon neutrality includes investing in high-quality carbon removal projects to offset the small amount of emissions that remain, demonstrating a comprehensive strategy towards achieving its environmental goals.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Committing to making all products carbon neutral by 2030

FedEx

 98 74

Environmental protection

FedEx is actively working towards a more sustainable future with a comprehensive approach that includes reducing emissions and waste, replacing older technologies and vehicles, and revolutionizing its facilities and packaging. The company has committed to achieving carbon-neutral operations by 2040, under its Priority Earth initiative. This commitment is supported by a $2 billion investment in vehicle electrification, sustainable energy, and carbon sequestration. FedEx is also focusing on reducing its carbon footprint through the FedExÂ® Fuel Sense program, which has saved around 164 million gallons of fuel and avoided more than 1.5 million metric tons of CO2e emissions. Additionally, FedEx is converting its entire parcel pickup and delivery fleet to zero-emission electric vehicles and investing in alternative fuels to reduce aircraft and vehicle emissions. The company is also enhancing its facilities with energy-efficient designs, renewable energy sources, and other energy management programs. FedEx's packaging strategies include using materials that are reusable, recyclable, and made from recycled content, with FedEx-branded cardboard packaging being 100% recyclable and composed of 36% recycled content. Furthermore, FedEx is a founding member of the Electrification Coalition Business Council, supporting policies and programs that accelerate the transition to electric vehicles.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Committing to achieving carbon-neutral operations by 2040

Toyota

 98 73

Environmental protection

Toyota is actively engaged in various environmental protection initiatives, focusing on reducing its environmental footprint and contributing positively to the planet. The company has set a goal to become carbon neutral across the vehicle life cycle by 2050, emphasizing its commitment to minimizing impacts on the environment. This goal is part of Toyota's broader Beyond Zero vision, which aims to go beyond achieving carbon neutrality in products, services, and operations to create a net positive impact on the planet and society. Toyota's environmental efforts include water conservation, reducing packaging and waste, and protecting biodiversity. The company is also purchasing over 340,000 MWh of renewable electricity in 2023 to power its North American operations, demonstrating its commitment to using renewable energy sources. Additionally, Toyota collaborates with environmental organizations such as The Nature Conservancy, Pollinator Partnership, and World Wildlife Fund, among others, to support various environmental projects and initiatives. These partnerships highlight Toyota's approach to working with external organizations to amplify its environmental impact.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Toyota is committed to ensuring the welfare of its workers through various initiatives and policies. The company believes in creating a diverse and inclusive work environment where every employee can demonstrate their abilities. Toyota's workforce in the U.S. is notably diverse, with 32.3% identifying as members of minority populations. The company also invests significantly in local communities, with an investment of $79.9 million in North America in 2022, which indirectly supports worker welfare by contributing to the overall well-being of the communities where its employees live and work. Furthermore, Toyota's commitment to diversity and inclusion (D&I) is integral to its corporate culture, aiming to make the workplace, marketplace, society, and the world better by living its values of equality, respect, and inclusive treatment of all people. This commitment is further evidenced by Toyota's recognition in the PRIDE INDEX 2023, where it was awarded the Gold Prize for its efforts in creating a welcoming workplace for sexual minorities such as LGBTQ+.

sources: 1, 2

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Committing to becoming carbon neutral across the vehicle life cycle by 2050

Colgate

 98 74

Environmental protection

Colgate-Palmolive has outlined a comprehensive strategy to protect the environment, focusing on several key areas. The company is committed to eliminating plastic waste by designing zero plastic waste solutions for its products, aiming to eliminate one-third of its new (virgin) plastics and make all of its plastic packaging recyclable, reusable, or compostable by 2025. In terms of water stewardship, Colgate-Palmolive aims for water resilience across its value chain, with goals to achieve Net Zero water at its manufacturing sites in water-stressed areas by 2025 and across all sites by 2030. The company is also accelerating action on climate change, targeting Net Zero carbon emissions across its value chain by 2040 and aiming for 100% renewable electricity for its global operations by 2030. Additionally, Colgate-Palmolive is focused on sustainable sourcing, engaging key suppliers to support its goal of sourcing sustainably and striving for zero deforestation, with a focus on palm and soy. The company also aims to lead with zero waste facilities, achieving 100% zero waste operations.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Colgate-Palmolive's 2025 Sustainability & Social Impact Strategy includes significant commitments to worker welfare. The company aims to inspire its people to make a difference by motivating and enabling them to reach their full potential and perform at their best every day. This involves valuing people for their contributions and sharing in the success created together. Additionally, Colgate-Palmolive is committed to creating a more inclusive world, ensuring all Colgate People feel they belong and are supported to achieve their potential. The company is driving representation across all organizational levels with a focused, consistent effort and a goal to achieve parity with labor force availability.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Colgate-Palmolive's sustainability strategy includes a commitment to fostering lifelong relationships between pets and people. The company supports its global shelter partners with resources and premium nutrition through the Hill's Food, Shelter & Love program. The ambitious goal of this program is to find adoption homes for 15 million shelter pets, demonstrating Colgate-Palmolive's commitment to animal welfare.

sources: 1

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found

    • Achieve Net Zero water at manufacturing sites in water-stressed areas by 2025 and across all sites by 2030
    • Target Net Zero carbon emissions across the value chain by 2040
    • Achieve 100% renewable electricity for global operations by 2030

Apple

 98 68

Environmental protection

Apple has made significant strides in environmental protection, aiming for carbon neutrality across all its products by 2030. The company has already achieved carbon neutrality for its corporate operations since 2020. Apple's environmental efforts include innovations in green chemistry and recycling, aiming to eventually manufacture products without extracting new resources from the earth. They are also focused on ensuring that their environmental initiatives promote equity and justice by collaborating with communities and local leaders. Apple's commitment to environmental sustainability is evident in their ambitious goal to make all their products carbon neutral within the next decade, highlighting their dedication to reducing carbon emissions, utilizing renewable resources, and innovating in recycling practices.

Lay's Chips

 98 78

Environmental protection

Frito-Lay, the company behind Lay's Chips, has undertaken several initiatives to protect the environment and promote sustainability. The company has made significant strides in harnessing renewable energy, such as switching its Modesto, CA plant to solar power and aiming for the Casa Grande facility to run primarily on renewable energy and recycled water. Frito-Lay has also committed to sustainable sourcing, with all its potatoes, corn, and direct oats being 100% sustainably sourced. The company has launched a sustainable farming program and is working towards eliminating 1.4 million metric tons of greenhouse gases through regenerative agricultural practices. Additionally, Frito-Lay has reduced its environmental impact by converting its fleet to all-electric vehicles and aiming to switch the fleet to 100% natural gas sourced from renewable resources. The company has also achieved 100% LED lighting in its manufacturing facilities and reduced packaging plastic by more than 7.8 million lbs since 2019, alongside reusing cardboard to save 2 million trees annually.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Frito-Lay has demonstrated a commitment to investing in communities and supporting worker welfare through various initiatives. The company's employees have volunteered nearly 4,000 hours to support their local communities. Frito-Lay has also supported over 420,000 youth through school meal programming and provided over 108 million meals to underserved communities. These efforts reflect the company's dedication to not only the welfare of its workers but also to the broader communities in which it operates.

sources: 1

Doritos

 98 75

Environmental protection

Doritos, under its parent company PepsiCo, has introduced a sustainable innovation with the launch of Doritos STAX. This new product line features a sustainable canister designed to be more environmentally friendly. The STAX canister is made to be widely recyclable in the paper waste stream, aligning with PepsiCo's broader goal of making 100% of its packaging recyclable, compostable, biodegradable, or reusable by 2025. The canister is crafted from responsibly sourced paperboard, representing a significant step towards reducing the environmental impact of packaging in the snack industry. This initiative not only addresses waste minimization but also promotes the use of sustainable materials in product packaging.

Kraft Mac & Cheese

 98 71

Environmental protection

Kraft Mac & Cheese is actively working on environmental protection through packaging innovation. They have announced the development and testing of the brand's first-ever recyclable fiber-based microwavable cup. This new packaging is designed to be microwave safe and aims to reduce plastic use by eliminating the plastic label through new direct print technology. The fiber-based cup is intended to be both recyclable and compostable in industrial composting facilities. Kraft Mac & Cheese is collaborating with external partners to certify and incorporate appropriate recycling labeling to guide consumers on how to dispose of the packaging sustainably after use. This initiative is part of Kraft Heinz Company's broader commitment to make 100% of its packaging recyclable, reusable, or compostable by 2025.

Dove

 98 74

Environmental protection

Dove is actively working towards environmental protection through various initiatives aimed at reducing plastic waste and carbon emissions. The brand has committed to reducing the manufacture of more than 20,500 tonnes of virgin plastic per year by making its iconic Beauty Bar packaging plastic-free globally, launching new 100% recycled plastic bottles, and trialing a new refillable deodorant format that significantly reduces plastic use. Dove's efforts extend to its manufacturing processes, where it aims to power its operations with 100% renewable energy. For instance, its USA and Germany sites already use renewable energy from wind and solar sources, and its Indonesian site is transitioning to sustainable biomass. Additionally, Dove is part of Unilever's broader commitment to halve the greenhouse gas (GHG) impacts of its products across their lifecycle by 2030. Dove also focuses on green shipping methods and innovative technology to reduce carbon emissions globally, including switching to liquid nitrogen gas (LNG) for lower emission fuels and building new LNG stations to support more environmentally friendly trucks.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Dove is proud to be PETA Approved, showcasing its commitment to cruelty-free beauty. The brand champions a global ban on animal testing for cosmetics, aligning with its ethical sourcing and sustainability efforts. This certification ensures that Dove products and their ingredients are not tested on animals, reflecting the brand's dedication to animal welfare and ethical beauty practices.

Macy's

 98 64

Environmental protection

Macy's, Inc. is actively engaged in efforts to minimize its environmental impact and promote sustainability. The company has implemented several initiatives aimed at reducing emissions, including the use of renewable energy through solar panels, managing energy consumption with automation systems, and retrofitting lighting with energy-efficient LED bulbs. In November 2022, Macy's committed to setting near-term company-wide emission reductions in alignment with climate science through the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi). Additionally, Macy's is focused on promoting circularity by investing in innovations that reduce, reuse, and repurpose materials, aiming to transition towards a more circular business model. The company is also an active member of various associations and networks that engage with policymakers on sustainability issues, demonstrating its commitment to advocating sustainable practices within the retail and fashion industry.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Macy's has established comprehensive programs to ensure that its private brands are produced in an ethical and responsible manner. The company closely monitors its supply chain to improve working conditions globally. Through rigorous screening of new suppliers, ongoing training, regular audits, and collaboration for improvement, Macy's ensures that its private brand suppliers adhere to high performance standards. This includes conducting third-party audits to identify issues and drive remediations when violations occur, demonstrating Macy's commitment to upholding human rights and improving worker welfare across its supply chain.

7-Eleven

 98 65

Environmental protection

7-Eleven is actively engaged in various initiatives to reduce its environmental impact and promote sustainability. The company has launched 7Charge, an EV charging network and app, to provide customers with alternative fuel options. It has also set ambitious goals to reduce CO2 emissions from its stores by 50% by 2030, building on its success in achieving a 20% reduction eight years ahead of schedule. To further this commitment, 7-Eleven has joined the Retail Industry Leaders Associationâs Retail Sustainability Initiative and the Clean Energy Buyers Alliance, collaborating with other members to address common environmental challenges.

The company has made significant strides in reducing energy consumption and CO2e emissions, achieving a 38% reduction from FY2013 to FY2022. This includes the adoption of Honeywell Solstice N40 refrigerant, which has a 60% lower global warming potential than traditional refrigerants, and the implementation of LED lighting and high-efficiency HVAC units in stores. 7-Eleven has also installed energy management systems in over 7,100 stores to optimize the performance of HVAC and refrigeration equipment.

In terms of renewable energy, approximately 26% of the electricity consumed by 7-Eleven is from renewable sources. The company has entered into agreements to purchase wind and solar energy in several states, including a 20-year clean energy commitment in Michigan through DTE Energyâs MIGreenPower program. This initiative aims to achieve 100% clean energy for all southeast Michigan locations, avoiding over 15,000 tons of carbon dioxide emissions annually.

sources: 1, 2

Clorox

 98 76

Environmental protection

Clorox is actively engaged in environmental protection efforts, focusing on climate action and waste reduction. The company has set an ambitious goal to reduce its virgin plastic and fiber packaging by 50% by 2030. This initiative is part of Clorox's broader commitment to tackle environmental challenges, including climate change and waste, to ensure a sustainable future. Additionally, Clorox has made significant progress towards its environmental goals, including surpassing its science-based target to reduce absolute scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions by 50 percent by 2030. The company also aims to achieve net-zero emissions across scopes 1, 2, and 3 by 2050. Clorox has reached its goal of sourcing 100% of its electricity from renewable energy for its U.S. and Canadian operations and has attained zero-waste-to-landfill status in nearly half of its facilities and more than three-quarters of its plants. Furthermore, Clorox is working towards having 100% recyclable, reusable, or compostable packaging by 2025, with 84% of this goal already achieved. The company has also been recognized as an Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) 2022 Safer Choice Partner of the Year for the fifth time, highlighting its commitment to manufacturing products with ingredients that are safer for human health and the environment.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Clorox has demonstrated a strong commitment to worker welfare, achieving and maintaining pay equity across gender globally and races/ethnicities in the U.S. for the last two years. This commitment ensures that there are no statistically significant differences in pay based on gender or race/ethnicity. Additionally, the company has been included in the Bloomberg Gender-Equality Index for the fifth consecutive year, which tracks the performance of public companies committed to transparency in gender-data reporting. Clorox also boasts a diverse corporate governance structure, with 50 percent of its board members being female and 25 percent belonging to minority groups. These efforts underscore Clorox's dedication to promoting equality and diversity within its workforce and leadership.

sources: 2

Nothing found

Baskin-Robbins

 98 75

Environmental protection

Baskin-Robbins has undertaken several initiatives to protect the environment, focusing on sustainable packaging and energy efficiency. The company has made significant strides in reducing its packaging waste by transitioning approximately 85% of its packaging to renewable, recyclable, and/or certified materials. Notably, in 2015, Baskin-Robbins transitioned its spoons to polypropylene, removing over 17,246 lbs. of packaging materials from the waste stream annually. The company is also exploring sustainable alternatives to single-use plastic packaging, including straws, to further reduce environmental impacts. Additionally, Baskin-Robbins is committed to water conservation, testing more efficient on-demand ice cream scoop washers that have demonstrated a significant reduction in water usage across test locations. In terms of energy and climate efforts, Baskin-Robbins, through external consultants, monitors its energy usage and Scope 1, 2, and 3 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions for corporate facilities, achieving a 60% reduction in GHG emissions in 2019 compared to a 2013 baseline.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Baskin-Robbins has shown a commitment to animal welfare through its policies and practices. The company does not own, raise, process, or transport livestock but recognizes the importance of animal welfare in a safe and sustainable food supply chain. In 2012, Baskin-Robbins created an Animal Welfare policy to communicate its commitments, set clear expectations for suppliers, and guide decision-making regarding animal products in its U.S. supply chain. Additionally, Baskin-Robbins requires all U.S. milk suppliers to participate in the Farmers Assuring Responsible Management (F.A.R.M.) program, which reflects U.S. dairy farmers' commitment to high levels of animal care and quality assurance, including a pledge not to use artificial growth hormones in cream and milk. The company has also joined the Dairy Sustainability Alliance, a multi-stakeholder group committed to sustainability and furthering the dairy community's social responsibility goals.

sources: 1

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Nothing found

Visa

 98 72

Environmental protection

Visa has implemented several initiatives to protect the environment and address climate change. The company achieved carbon neutrality across its operations starting in 2020 through energy efficiency initiatives, transitioning to 100% renewable electricity, and using carbon offsets for its residual footprint. These offsets include projects in forest preservation, reforestation, renewable energy, and clean cookstoves. Visa has committed to achieving net-zero emissions by 2040, aligning with the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) at the 1.5-degree Celsius ambition level, a goal approved by SBTi in May 2022.

In its operations, Visa focuses on minimizing environmental impact through green building design and operation, obtaining LEED certifications, and increasing resource use efficiency. The company has also transitioned to using 100% renewable electricity as of 2020 and continues to explore additional renewable energy opportunities. Visa engages in sustainable business travel and events, promoting green travel choices and hosting zero waste events. The company is engaging suppliers to reduce emissions and participates in the Carbon Disclosure Project (CDP) Supply Chain program. Visa supports employee commuting to offices in more sustainable ways and has issued a $500 million green bond to finance environmentally friendly projects.

Visa also promotes sustainable commerce by supporting alternative card materials to reduce the environmental footprint of payment cards, working with partners to offer "sustainability-as-a-service" offerings, and supporting sustainable consumer behaviors in areas like mobility, travel, and tourism. The company is a founding partner of Brands for Good, aiming to make sustainable living more attractive and attainable.

sources: 1, 2

Nothing found

Nissan

 98 61

Environmental protection

Nissan is actively working towards environmental sustainability with a comprehensive strategy that includes achieving carbon neutrality by 2050 across its operations and product lifecycle. In 2022, Nissan reported a 41.2% reduction in CO2 emissions from new vehicles compared to the year 2000. The company has committed to electrifying all new Nissan vehicle offerings in key markets by the early 2030s. This commitment is part of Nissan's broader environmental goals, which align with the U.N. Paris Agreement on climate change and global efforts toward carbon neutrality. The Nissan Green Program (NGP) is Nissan's environmental action plan focusing on climate change, resource dependency, air quality, and water scarcity. The company is innovating in electrification technologies, emphasizing EV battery innovations, and planning to expand recycling from scrapped vehicles to reduce CO2 emissions and the use of new resources. Nissan also implements systems and control standards at its production plants to minimize air pollutants and is developing new methods to reduce water usage across its manufacturing plants worldwide. Additionally, Nissan supports Tread Lightly!'s mission to keep recreation areas accessible and healthy for future generations. The company has received several awards for its environmental efforts, including the ENERGY STARÂ® Partner of the Year recognition for 14 years, a commendation on the CDP A list 2022 for leadership on climate change and water security, and the Better Project Award 2021 for its achievements in energy efficiency.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Nissan is committed to creating a diverse, equitable, and inclusive workplace. The company's global workforce represents over 100 nationalities, and the ratio of women managers globally has increased from 6.7% in 2008 to 15.5% in 2023. This effort is part of Nissan's broader goal to ensure that every individual is valued, respected, and empowered, contributing to a more inclusive world where people are engaged, healthy, and happy.

sources: 1

Netflix

 98 69

Environmental protection

Netflix is actively working towards environmental sustainability by setting and pursuing specific climate targets. In 2021, the company's carbon footprint was approximately 1.5 million metric tons, with over half of that footprint stemming from the physical production of shows and films. Netflix has committed to cutting its emissions in half by 2030, a goal validated by a science-based target. Additionally, starting in 2022, Netflix has been bringing its net carbon footprint to zero annually by investing in nature-based solutions to capture carbon. This approach aligns with the guidelines set forth by the International Organization for Standardization (ISO). To further its environmental protection efforts, Netflix has implemented a strategy focusing on optimizing energy use, electrifying vehicles, utilizing clean mobile power, and employing renewable energy within its production processes. This comprehensive approach has already resulted in a 10% reduction in emissions in 2021 compared to what they would have been without these initiatives. Netflix also invests in high-quality nature-based carbon credits to offset its remaining emissions, adhering to the latest guidance from various research and environmental organizations.

sources: 1, 2

  • Commitments
    • Halve emissions by 2030
    • Annually bring net carbon footprint to zero starting in 2022

Target

 98 64

Environmental protection

Target is actively working towards environmental protection through various initiatives aimed at reducing carbon emissions, minimizing waste, and promoting renewable energy usage. The company has set science-based targets for emissions reductions across scopes 1, 2, and 3 and joined the Business Ambition for 1.5Â°C to align with efforts to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. Target is on track to achieve its goal of sourcing 100% renewable electricity by 2030, having already reached 60% as of FY2022. The company also emphasizes circular design principles, focusing on material choice, durability, repairability, and recyclability in its owned brands, Universal Thread and Everspring. Additionally, Target has committed to sustainable packaging by becoming signatories to the New Plastics Economy and the U.S. Plastics Pact, aiming to reduce virgin plastic use in owned brand packaging by 20% from a 2020 baseline and ensure all owned brand plastic packaging is recyclable, compostable, or reusable by 2025. Target's commitment to environmental sustainability is further demonstrated by its aim to achieve net zero greenhouse gas emissions across its enterprise by 2040 and its goal to achieve zero waste to landfill in U.S. operations by 2030.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Target is committed to ensuring worker welfare through various initiatives focused on equitable and inclusive employment practices. The company aims to create a sustainable and inclusive supply chain that is just and equitable for all workers. Target has laid foundations for responsible sourcing commitments for various raw materials and has launched a commitment to spend more than $2 billion with Black-owned businesses by the end of 2025. Furthermore, Target plans for all owned brand suppliers to have policies and programs in place by 2025 to advance gender equity, focusing on equitable hiring and advancement systems, financial security, anonymous incident reporting channels, and access to gender-responsive health information and services. The company has also invested in CAREâs Dignified Work Initiative and became a member of the Better Than Cash Alliance to support digital payments for workers by 2025. Target's efforts to ensure worker welfare are part of its broader commitment to diversity, equity, inclusion, and belonging, with updated DE&I goals announced in 2022.

sources: 1, 2

Cheerios

 98 74

Environmental protection

Cheerios, through its parent company General Mills, is actively engaged in environmental protection efforts, particularly in the area of sustainable agriculture. A significant focus is placed on sourcing oats that are resilient to heat and drought, which is crucial for reducing the environmental impact of their supply chain. Moreover, Cheerios is committed to supporting regenerative agriculture practices. This approach not only aims to enhance ecosystem health but also seeks to sequester carbon, thereby contributing to the mitigation of climate change. The company has made a specific commitment to advance regenerative agriculture practices on 1 million acres by 2030. This initiative is expected to improve soil health, increase biodiversity, and reduce the need for chemical pesticides, showcasing Cheerios' dedication to environmental stewardship and sustainable farming practices.

Wendy's

 98 71

Environmental protection

Wendy's is actively working on several fronts to reduce its environmental impact. The company has committed to sustainably sourcing 100% of its customer-facing packaging by 2026, acknowledging the growing concern among consumers regarding packaging waste. In addition to packaging, Wendy's has conducted its first greenhouse gas (GHG) inventory in 2020 and is in the process of setting a science-based target for GHG emissions reduction by the end of 2023. Water conservation is another area of focus, with the company committed to reducing the water usage in its operations. Furthermore, Wendy's is dedicated to minimizing food waste through its focus on fresh ingredients and making food to order. At the corporate level, Wendy's Restaurant Support Center and company-operated restaurants have achieved a 17% reduction in energy per square foot against a 2012 baseline, equivalent to removing nearly 5,000 cars from the road. The company also pilots sustainability initiatives in a designated restaurant to test new materials and methods that could potentially be implemented across the brand.

sources: 1, 2

Audi

 98 59

Environmental protection

Audi is actively working towards reducing its carbon footprint and achieving net COâ neutrality by 2050. The company has set ambitious goals, including a 30% reduction in its carbon footprint by 2025 compared to 2019 levels. Audi's production facilities globally are planned to be certified net carbon-neutral by 2025, with the Audi Brussels plant already achieving this certification in 2018. Additionally, Audi is committed to the Paris Climate Agreement, aiming to limit global warming to 2 degrees Celsius by cutting emissions of carbon dioxide and other greenhouse gases. The company is also the first car manufacturer to be awarded the Chain of Custody certificate of the Aluminium Stewardship Initiative (ASI), ensuring sustainability standards for aluminum production and recycling. Audi is a member of the Global Battery Alliance, focusing on human rights and social standards in the mining of raw materials for batteries and developing solutions for the reuse of lithium-ion batteries. The company is exploring second-use applications and the recycling and re-use of battery materials to improve the life cycle sustainability of its batteries.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Audi engages actively at its production locations worldwide to create a future worth living in, focusing on the environment, education, culture, and sport. The company takes responsibility for its supply chain, advocates for human rights, and promotes diversity and inclusion. Audi's commitment to social responsibility is part of its holistic sustainability approach, which includes taking social responsibility in addition to ecological criteria. The company has also committed to providing 500 million euros by 2025 for training employees, ensuring their welfare and development.

sources: 1, 2

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Chain of Custody certificate of the Aluminium Stewardship Initiative (ASI)
  • Commitments
    • Reduce COâ emissions over the next decade and achieve net COâ neutrality by 2050
    • 30% reduction in carbon footprint by 2025, compared to 2019
    • All production facilities to be certified net carbon-neutral by 2025
    • 30% of the US model lineup to be full battery electric or plug-in hybrid by 2025
    • Support and align actions with the goals of the Paris Climate Agreement

Play-Doh

 98 73

Environmental protection

Hasbro, the parent company of Play-Doh, has implemented a comprehensive Climate Action Plan aimed at reducing its carbon footprint and enhancing climate resilience. This plan is divided into two parts: the first focuses on reducing Greenhouse Gases (GHGs), while the second addresses climate risk and resilience, including the potential financial impacts of climate change on the business. A significant step in their environmental protection efforts is their commitment to the Science-Based Target initiative (SBTi), aligning with the Paris Agreement to limit global warming to 1.5Â°C. Hasbro has set ambitious goals to reduce absolute Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions by 47.5% and Scope 3 GHG emissions by 42% by 2030 from a 2020 base year. Furthermore, they aim to reduce absolute Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions by 90% by 2050 from the same base year.

Hasbro's Sustainability Center of Excellence drives their Environmental Blueprint, focusing on Design for the Environment, Sustainable Supply Chain & Production, and Facilities & Culture. They are committed to improving the sustainability of their products and packaging through the use of alternative materials, responsible procurement practices, and innovative product designs. Notably, Hasbro has introduced sustainable versions of popular products, including the Play-Doh Grow Your Garden Toolset, using more sustainable materials such as plant-based or recycled plastics and FSCÂ®-certified materials.

The company has also made strides in sustainable packaging by eliminating wire ties, adding How2RecycleÂ® labeling, eliminating Styrofoam in new products, and using recycled or sustainably sourced paper. They aim for 90% of paper and in-box content in their products to be made from recycled or sustainably-sourced paper and are exploring the use of plant-based bioplastic components.

Hasbro's Toy Recycling Program, launched in 2018, offers consumers a sustainable option for recycling their toys and games, diverting over 45,000 pounds of waste from landfills. This program exemplifies Hasbro's commitment to product disposal and takeback, providing a second life for materials through upcycling.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • FSCÂ®-certified materials
    • How2RecycleÂ® labeling
  • Commitments
    • Reduce absolute Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions by 47.5% by 2030 from a 2020 base year
    • Reduce absolute Scope 3 GHG emissions by 42% by 2030 from a 2020 base year
    • Reduce absolute Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions by 90% by 2050 from a 2020 base year

Costco

 98 69

Environmental protection

Costco is actively working towards environmental protection through various sustainability efforts. The company has established a Climate Action Plan as a roadmap to lower carbon dioxide-equivalent (CO2e) emissions. This plan is part of Costco's broader sustainability commitment, which aligns with several United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) that are most relevant to their business operations. These goals include Clean Water & Sanitation, Decent Work & Economic Growth, Reduced Inequalities, Responsible Consumption & Production, Climate Action, Life Below Water, and Life On Land. Costco's sustainability efforts are integrated into their business model, focusing on issues where they can make a real, positive impact. The company emphasizes the importance of a just transition to a low carbon business model, ensuring that their decarbonization objectives align with their commitments to human rights, diversity, equity, inclusion, and environmental conservation. Costco's governance and reporting on climate-related matters are detailed in their Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD) section, showcasing their commitment to transparency and continuous improvement in their environmental efforts.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Costco's sustainability commitment extends to ensuring worker welfare. The company's efforts are grounded in their Mission Statement and Code of Ethics, which emphasize the importance of treating employees well. Costco's sustainability commitment outlines their approach to inclusion, employee development, community investment, and supplier diversity. The company has set goals for an inclusive workplace and actively works towards diversity within Costco. They focus on employee development through various programs and benefits, aiming to improve workforce tenure and development. Additionally, Costco engages in charitable contributions and food donations to support communities. The company also has a strong commitment to human rights, ensuring fair treatment for employees and communities, as well as within their supply chain. These efforts demonstrate Costco's dedication to creating a positive and supportive environment for their workers and the broader community.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Costco is committed to promoting animal welfare through its business practices. The company's sustainability commitment includes a section on animal welfare, where they outline their mission statement and approach to ensuring the humane treatment of animals used in their products. Costco collaborates with experts and suppliers to implement a scope and risk-based phased approach to animal welfare. They conduct animal welfare audits and have specific policies in place, such as Costco's Broiler Policy and their commitment to sourcing cage-free eggs. The company also addresses the welfare of beef, dairy, veal, pork, and the use of antibiotics. Costco's vertically integrated poultry facility is part of their effort to maintain control over the welfare of animals in their supply chain. These initiatives reflect Costco's commitment to minimizing animal suffering and promoting health and welfare standards.

sources: 1

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Aligning with United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) related to their business operations
    • Lowering carbon dioxide-equivalent (CO2e) emissions through their Climate Action Plan
    • Promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion in the workplace
    • Ensuring the humane treatment of animals used in their products

Domino's

 98 60

Environmental protection

Domino's has outlined a comprehensive approach to reducing its environmental impact, focusing on climate, water, and waste. The company has committed to ambitious emissions reductions targets aligned with the Science-Based Targets initiative (SBTi), aiming for significant reductions in greenhouse gas emissions across its operations and value chain by 2032 and 2050. These targets include a 50.4% reduction in scope 1 and 2 emissions, a 30% reduction in scope 3 non-FLAG emissions, and a 36.4% reduction in scope 3 FLAG emissions by 2032, with further reductions by 2050. Domino's decarbonization strategy involves improving efficiency, electrification, and the use of renewable energy. This includes piloting energy management systems, transitioning to LED lighting, rolling out electric delivery vehicles, and developing a renewable energy roadmap. Additionally, Domino's is engaging with suppliers to reduce the carbon footprint of its top ingredients, which are predominantly animal-based products.

In terms of water stewardship, Domino's has begun assessing its overall water risk using tools from the World Resources Institute and the World Wildlife Fund. This assessment aims to identify and evaluate ways to reduce risk through better data, supplier partnership, and operational efficiencies.

Domino's is also focused on waste reduction and sustainable packaging. The company is developing new policies around waste reduction and diversion and is transitioning to more sustainable packaging. Efforts include recycling excess dough, reducing operational waste, increasing the recycled fiber content of pizza boxes, and exploring ways to reduce or eliminate single-use plastic utensils and packaging.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Reduce absolute scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions 50.4% by 2032 from a 2021 base year.
    • Reduce absolute scope 3 non-FLAG GHG emissions 30% by 2032 from a 2021 base year.
    • Reduce absolute Scope 3 FLAG GHG emissions 36.4% by 2032 from a 2021 base year.
    • Reduce absolute scope 1, 2, and 3 non-FLAG GHG emissions 90% by 2050 from a 2021 base year.
    • Reduce absolute scope 3 FLAG GHG emissions 72% by 2050 from a 2021 base year.

Crest

 97 77

Environmental protection

Crest and Oral-B are actively working towards reducing their environmental impact through several initiatives. They are striving to achieve 100% renewable electricity usage across their Canadian manufacturing plants and aim to eliminate manufacturing waste sent to landfills. The brands are also working towards more localized manufacturing within Canada to decrease logistics-based emissions. In partnership with Terracycle, Crest and Oral-B have introduced Canada's first oral care recycling program, offering consumers a way to recycle used products. The Oral-B Clic manual toothbrush, which uses 60% less plastic, was recognized for its sustainability efforts by Fast Company's 2020 Innovation by Design Awards. Additionally, Crest is transitioning to recyclable HDPE toothpaste tubes, with a goal of complete conversion to 100% recyclable tubes by 2025. They are also implementing How2Recycle labels on selected product packaging to educate consumers on proper recycling practices.

Bank of America

 97 48

Environmental protection

Bank of America is actively engaged in various initiatives to protect the environment and transition to a low-carbon, sustainable economy. The bank has committed to achieving net-zero greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions in its financing activities, operations, and supply chain before 2050. As part of its Environmental Business Initiative, Bank of America aims to deploy and mobilize $1 trillion by 2030 towards accelerating the transition to a low-carbon economy. This initiative focuses on financing low-carbon energy, energy efficiency, sustainable transportation, water conservation, land use, and waste management solutions. Additionally, the bank has achieved carbon neutrality and procured 100% renewable electricity in 2019, a year ahead of its schedule. Bank of America also emphasizes the importance of managing environmental and social risks and provides industry-leading disclosures on its progress, aligning with the Global Reporting Initiative standards.
