EstÃ©e Lauder

 90 52

Environmental protection

EstÃ©e Lauder has implemented several initiatives to protect the environment, focusing on climate action, sustainable building operations, waste reduction, and water stewardship. The company aims to minimize environmental impacts by setting targets to reduce direct and indirect emissions, creating more sustainable building practices, sending zero waste to landfill at their facilities, and improving water efficiency. Additionally, EstÃ©e Lauder has committed to carbon neutrality across its Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions and ensures that 100% of its palm-based ingredients are RSPO certified. The company also highlights that 99% of its forest-based fiber cartons are FSC certified. EstÃ©e Lauder's e-commerce data center in North America is powered by renewable electricity, and the company has set a goal that by 2025, 75-100% of its packaging will meet at least one of the â5 Rsâ: recyclable, refillable, reusable, recycled, or recoverable. They aim to increase the amount of post-consumer recycled material in their packaging by up to 50% and have 100% of their forest-based fiber cartons FSC-certified by 2025. Furthermore, EstÃ©e Lauder offsets the carbon emissions from shipping for every U.S. home delivery order placed on esteelauder.com through funding to the Doe Mountain Improved Forest Management Project. This project protects a stretch of mixed-hardwood forest across 8,600 acres in Northeastern Tennessee, promoting forest health and supporting carbon sequestration 1, 2, 3.

Worker welfare

EstÃ©e Lauder is committed to ensuring the welfare of its workers and has implemented various initiatives to support this commitment. The company's efforts include sourcing ingredients and materials responsibly with attention to potential impacts on people and the environment. EstÃ©e Lauder works diligently to source ingredients responsibly, aiming to continuously improve and strengthen its sourcing practices while remaining sensitive to the local communities in which it operates. Additionally, the company has made a significant financial commitment through the ELC Charitable Foundation to the Breast Cancer Research Foundation over five years. EstÃ©e Lauder also reported spending $162M with women-owned businesses in FY23, surpassing its $150M goal. These initiatives demonstrate EstÃ©e Lauder's dedication to supporting its workers and the broader community 1, 3.

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • FSC certified for forest-based fiber cartons
    • RSPO certified for palm-based ingredients
  • Commitments
    • Achieving carbon neutrality across Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions
    • Ensuring 75-100% of packaging meets at least one of the â5 Rsâ by 2025
    • Increasing the amount of post-consumer recycled material in packaging by up to 50% by 2025
    • Having 100% of forest-based fiber cartons FSC-certified by 2025

Dove men+care

 90 61

Environmental protection

Dove Men+Care is actively working to reduce its environmental impact, particularly in the area of plastic waste. The brand has committed to halving its use of virgin plastic by 2025 through a strategy of using less plastic, better plastic, or no plastic at all, aiming for a transition to a circular economy. This initiative includes the launch of 100% recycled plastic bottles in North America and Europe, where technically feasible, and the introduction of a 0% Aluminum Refillable Deodorant with a stainless steel case and recyclable refills made from 98% recycled plastic. Dove Men+Care's efforts are part of a broader commitment by Dove to reduce plastic waste, including making its iconic Beauty Bar packaging plastic-free globally, launching new 100% recycled plastic bottles, and trialing a new refillable deodorant format to radically reduce plastic use. These actions are expected to reduce Dove's use of virgin plastic by more than 20,500 tonnes a year. Dove is following a NOâBETTERâLESS PLASTIC framework, which includes initiatives to eliminate plastic where possible, invest in sustainable plastic choices, and reduce the overall use of plastic through innovations like the minimâ¢ technology for deodorant sticks. These efforts are part of Unilever's commitment to make all its plastic packaging reusable, recyclable, or compostable by 2025.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Dove Men+Care is committed to animal welfare, ensuring that its products are not tested on animals. The brand has received approval from PETA, highlighting its long-standing commitment against animal testing. This certification is part of Dove's broader commitment to ethical sourcing and sustainability, emphasizing care not only for consumers but also for animals.

sources: 1

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • PETA Approved
  • Commitments
    • Halving virgin plastic use by 2025
    • Making all plastic packaging reusable, recyclable, or compostable by 2025

Busch

 90 37

Environmental protection

Busch, under its parent company Anheuser-Busch, has committed to a more sustainable future by focusing on four key areas across its supply chain: sustainable agriculture, water stewardship, renewable electricity and carbon reduction, and circular packaging. The company has set ambitious goals for 2025, including ensuring 100% of its direct farmers are highly skilled, connected, and financially empowered; all facilities are engaged in water efficiency efforts with measurably improved water availability and quality in high-stress areas; 100% of purchased electricity comes from renewable sources with a 25% reduction in CO2 emissions across the value chain; and all packaging is made from majority recycled content or is returnable. Furthermore, Anheuser-Busch has a global ambition to achieve net-zero by 2040, demonstrating a commitment to reducing its environmental impact and contributing to a more sustainable planet. These initiatives are part of the company's broader sustainability strategy, which is governed by a Sustainability Council and informed by materiality assessments to ensure focus on critical environmental issues. The company also engages with external environmental advisors and participates in industry associations to strengthen its approach to sustainable development.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • 100% of direct farmers will be highly-skilled, connected, and financially empowered by 2025
    • 100% of facilities will be engaged in water efficiency efforts; and 100% of communities in high-stress areas will have measurably improved water availability and quality by 2025
    • 100% of purchased electricity will come from renewable sources and CO2 emissions across the value chain will be reduced by 25% by 2025
    • 100% of packaging will be made from majority recycled content or will be returnable by 2025
    • Achieve net-zero by 2040

Sensodyne

 90 60

Environmental protection

Sensodyne, under its parent company GSK Consumer Healthcare, has initiated significant steps towards environmental sustainability, particularly in packaging. The brand has partnered with two global packaging suppliers, Albea and EPL Global, to transition its toothpaste tubes to fully recyclable materials. The collaboration with Albea involves switching to Greenleaf laminate tubes, starting with Sensodyne Pronamel in Europe. Similarly, the partnership with EPL Global will produce tubes using Platina laminate. Both materials have been approved by the Association of Plastic Recyclers (APR) and Europe's RecyClass, ensuring they are recyclable and compatible with existing recycling processes. This initiative is expected to make over a billion toothpaste tubes recyclable by 2025. Additionally, Sensodyne has launched its Nourish toothpaste range with fully recyclable packaging, including the tube, cap, and carton, with the carton made from recycled board. These efforts are part of GSK's broader commitment to achieving a net-zero impact on climate and a positive impact on nature by 2030.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Sensodyne's Nourish toothpaste range is vegan friendly, indicating that it contains no animal products or derivatives. This commitment suggests a consideration for animal welfare by avoiding the use of animal-derived ingredients in their products.

sources: 2

Transparency

  • Certifications

    • Nothing found

  • Commitments

    • Fully recyclable packaging for Sensodyne toothpaste tubes by 2025
    • Net-zero impact on climate and a positive impact on nature by 2030

Nestle Crunch Dark Bar

 90 59

Environmental protection

NestlÃ© has taken significant steps towards environmental protection through its packaging and sourcing initiatives. The company has announced the launch of its YES! snack bars in a new recyclable paper wrapper, marking a significant innovation in the confectionery industry. This packaging is made possible by a high-speed flow wrap technology that allows paper to be used at large scale while ensuring product quality and freshness. The paper wrapper is widely recycled in the countries where it will be available and is sourced from sustainable sources, certified by the Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) and The Program for the Endorsement of Forest Certification. This initiative is part of NestlÃ©'s broader commitment to make all its packaging recyclable or reusable by 2025, aiming to reduce plastic waste and promote sustainability in its operations. Additionally, NestlÃ© sources 100% certified cocoa beans for its CRUNCHÂ® bars through the NestlÃ© Cocoa Plan, which aims to improve the lives of cocoa farmers and assure a sustainable cocoa supply. The beans are certified by UTZ Certified, focusing on sustainable farming and better opportunities for farmers and their families.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

NestlÃ©'s commitment to worker welfare is evident through its NestlÃ© Cocoa Plan, which is designed to improve the livelihoods of cocoa farmers and ensure a sustainable cocoa supply. The plan includes a variety of social and economic programs aimed at enhancing the quality of life for cocoa farmers and their families. These initiatives encompass education and training for thousands of farmers, distribution of millions of higher-yielding plants, and improvements to infrastructure in farming communities. Additionally, the plan focuses on building or refurbishing schools and addressing the elimination of child labor in the cocoa supply chain. By sourcing 100% certified cocoa beans for its CRUNCHÂ® bars, NestlÃ© not only ensures the quality and sustainability of its products but also supports the well-being of the farmers involved in its supply chain.

sources: 2

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Forest Stewardship Council (FSC)
    • The Program for the Endorsement of Forest Certification
    • UTZ Certified
  • Commitments
    • Commitment to make all packaging recyclable or reusable by 2025

Ferrero Rocher

 90 65

Environmental protection

Ferrero Rocher is actively working towards reducing its environmental impact through various initiatives. One of the key areas of focus is on developing more sustainable packaging solutions. Since September 2021, Ferrero Rocher has started to introduce eco-designed boxes for its products, beginning with its most iconic ones: the 16-piece and 30-piece compact boxes. This move towards eco-designed packaging is part of Ferrero Rocher's broader commitment to sustainability and reducing its impact on the environment. Additionally, the company emphasizes the importance of caring for the environment and the communities where it operates, aiming to preserve and enhance the natural resources and support local communities through education and farmer training.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Ferrero Rocher is committed to improving the livelihoods of cocoa farmers within its supply chain. This commitment is demonstrated through its receipt of the Fairtrade Germany Award in March 2018, recognizing the company's long-term efforts to source cocoa responsibly. Ferrero Rocher's approach to sustainability includes working closely with local farmers to produce high-quality ingredients, which involves supporting them through training and education. This not only helps in ensuring the quality of the ingredients but also contributes to the welfare of the farmers and their communities by aiming to improve their livelihoods and ensuring sustainable farming practices.

sources: 1, 2

These actions reflect Nationwide's long-term goals towards achieving environmental sustainability and reducing its environmental impact.

Nationwide is committed to cultivating an inclusive culture where every associate is valued, engaged, and respected. This approach ensures that all employees thrive in an environment that appreciates their contributions and respects their differences, fostering a sense of belonging and success for every associate.

Sleep Number

 90 52

Environmental protection

Sleep Number has demonstrated a commitment to environmental stewardship through various initiatives aimed at reducing its carbon footprint and enhancing operational efficiencies. The company has been actively measuring and focusing on reducing its Scope 1 and 2 greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions and has initiated an assessment of its Scope 3 GHG emissions. A significant step in its environmental efforts includes the completion of a multi-year transition to an integrated manufacturing and distribution network. This transition is expected to yield numerous environmental benefits, such as waste reduction, cost savings, and an improved customer experience. These efforts align with Sleep Number's commitment to the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) and its principles in areas including the environment.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Sleep Number has taken steps to ensure the welfare of its workers and the broader community through various social initiatives. The company has established a cross-functional social impact team to coordinate and communicate its social initiatives enterprise-wide. Financial commitments and collaborations with organizations such as the Mayo Clinic and the American Cancer Society highlight Sleep Number's dedication to societal wellbeing. Additionally, the company sponsors multiple sleep research studies, demonstrating its commitment to improving health and wellbeing through better sleep. Sleep Number's efforts in diversity, equity, and inclusion (DE&I) initiatives further underscore its commitment to an inclusive and supportive workplace environment.

Dyson

 90 63

Environmental protection

Dyson's approach to environmental protection is centered around innovation and efficiency in product design and operations. The company has made strides in creating high-performing, efficient machines that use fewer resources. Notable efforts include the development of the Dyson digital motor, which is lighter and consumes less electrical energy than standard motors, and the use of cyclone technology in vacuum cleaners to eliminate the need for wasteful bags. Dyson has also focused on improving the efficiency and onboard performance of its technology through software enhancements. In terms of product components, Dyson engineers high-performance HEPA filters for air purifiers using 85% recycled materials and has developed batteries with higher energy density for better performance. The company has also introduced products like the Recycloneâ¢, made from recycled plastic, and the Dyson Airblade 9kJ hand dryer, which produces up to 88% less COâ emissions than paper towels. Additionally, Dyson purifiers are designed to automatically sense and react to indoor air pollution, capturing 99.95% of microscopic pollutants and reducing energy consumption when air quality is safe. Dyson's lighting solutions incorporate Heat Pipe technology to maintain light quality for up to 60 years, further demonstrating the company's commitment to sustainability through product innovation.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Measure and improve environmental impacts of operations and products, including energy use, greenhouse gas emissions, water consumption, and waste
    • Design products, packaging, and behaviors to reduce environmental impacts
    • Reduce primary material demand through resource recovery and reuse
    • Improve resource efficiency and address pollution, including adopting renewable energy supplies
    • Support Contract Manufacturers, suppliers, and subcontractors to adopt the same environmental commitments
    • Complete an annual review including progress against targets

L'Oreal Paris

 90 51

Environmental protection

L'Oreal Paris has launched a comprehensive sustainability program, "LâOrÃ©al For the Future, Because our Planet is Worth it," aiming to significantly reduce its environmental footprint across the entire value chain by 2030. The brand is committed to reducing its carbon footprint by 50% per finished product and has pledged to contribute 10 million Euros to environmental projects benefiting communities of women around the world. Key initiatives include optimizing packaging to accelerate the shift to a circular economy, improving the biodegradability of their formulas, and reducing water usage. Notably, L'Oreal Paris is working towards using 100% recycled or biobased plastic by 2030 and has already made strides by targeting 100% recycled PET for shampoo and conditioner bottles in Europe. The brand's factories and distribution centers have significantly reduced CO2 emissions, water consumption, and waste generation, with plans for all factories to be carbon neutral by 2025. Additionally, L'Oreal Paris is investing in environmental projects that empower women, recognizing their crucial role in combating climate change.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

L'Oreal Paris, as part of the L'Oreal Group, is committed to beauty without animal testing. The company has been at the forefront of alternative methods for over 30 years, ensuring that their products are safe and effective without the need for animal testing. This commitment is part of their broader sustainability and ethical efforts to minimize their impact on the environment and promote more humane practices across their operations.

Dolby

 90 64

Environmental protection

Dolby is actively pursuing a range of initiatives to protect the environment and mitigate climate change impacts. The company has committed to becoming carbon neutral by 2030, a goal that encompasses a broad spectrum of activities aimed at reducing its environmental footprint. Dolby has validated its science-based targets with the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi), marking a significant step towards reducing emissions across its operations. In 2022, Dolby achieved 100% renewable electricity for its global operations through a combination of green tariffs and Energy Attribute Certificates. Additionally, Dolby has made strides in solar energy by installing its first solar project in Sunnyvale, California, in April 2023. The company also invests in carbon offset projects that offer both environmental and social benefits, aligning with the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs). These projects include afforestation efforts in mainland China and promoting household solar energy in India, demonstrating Dolby's commitment to a sustainable and equitable future.

sources: 1, 2

Comcast

 90 37

Environmental protection

Comcast is actively working towards reducing its environmental impact through various initiatives aimed at achieving carbon neutrality and enhancing energy efficiency. The company has set a goal to become carbon neutral for Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 2035. Significant progress has been made towards this goal, with Comcast having eliminated 960,000 tons of greenhouse gas emissions since 2019, which is equivalent to removing 200,000 cars from the road for a year. This achievement represents a 38% reduction in emissions from their operations since 2019. Comcast is committed to investing in clean and renewable energy, having sourced more than 1.2 million megawatt-hours of clean and renewable energy in 2022. This effort is equivalent to avoiding the emissions from 170,000 homesâ electricity use for a year. The company is also focusing on network efficiency, deploying new, energy-efficient technologies across its network. By 2030, Comcast estimates these technologies will avoid the equivalent amount of electricity needed to power half a million homes for a year. Additionally, Comcast has joined the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) on climate action, committing to set near-term emission reduction goals in line with pathways designed to limit global warming. The company's sustainability efforts extend to its products and packaging, with initiatives like the introduction of Sky Glass, the worldâs first TV certified as a CarbonNeutralÂ® product, and The Xfinity Eco Capsuleâ¢, a 100% recyclable and reusable modular packaging system made with renewable materials.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

  • Commitments
    • Committing to become carbon neutral for Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 2035
    • Joining the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi) on climate action

Mary Kay Cosmetics

 90 39

Environmental protection

Mary Kay Cosmetics has implemented several initiatives under its "Pink Doing Green" program to protect the environment. These efforts include achieving LEED certification for new building projects, reducing operational waste sent to landfills, planting over a million trees to support carbon reduction efforts, and improving water efficiency in manufacturing facilities. Additionally, the company is committed to reducing its carbon footprint, finding sustainable solutions to operational waste, responsibly using water, and protecting ethically sourced resources essential for healthy living. Mary Kay's commitment to environmental protection is part of its broader sustainability strategy, which aligns with the United Nations' Sustainable Development Goals, making it a part of a global coalition for a better future.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Mary Kay Cosmetics has demonstrated a strong commitment to worker welfare through various initiatives. The company has garnered 13 employer/great place to work awards and was ranked #8 on the list of "The Companies Employees Donât Want to Leave," published by Resume.io. Mary Kay has released gender diversity data, showing that its executive team is 54% female, managers and above are 59% female, and 62% of the total workforce is female. In 2021, the company scored 75% in employee engagement, which is 10% over the global average for employee engagement. These efforts reflect Mary Kay's dedication to nurturing its company culture and ensuring a supportive and inclusive work environment for its employees.

sources: 2

Jaguar

 90 54

Environmental protection

Jaguar, under its parent company Jaguar Land Rover (JLR), is actively working towards environmental sustainability through various initiatives aimed at reducing carbon emissions and promoting the use of renewable energy. The company has committed to achieving net zero carbon emissions across its supply chain, products, and operations by 2039. This ambitious goal is part of JLR's Reimagine strategy, which includes the electrification of both the Jaguar and Land Rover brands. By the end of the decade, all Jaguar and Land Rover nameplates will be available in pure electric form. Jaguar is set to become an all-electric luxury brand from 2025, and Land Rover will introduce six pure electric variants in the next five years, with the first all-electric model expected in 2024.

JLR has also focused on sustainable operations by paying attention to the facilities that manufacture its vehicles. The Advanced Product Centre in Gaydon, UK, has been extended and redeveloped to include over 11 hectares of new landscaping, increasing the site's natural habitat by 25% and incorporating a 3,000m2 rooftop solar array. The company has successfully reduced its global vehicle manufacturing operating CO2 by 46% per vehicle and remains committed to further decarbonization.

In addition to vehicle electrification and sustainable operations, JLR is pioneering in the use of recycled materials and the development of circular economy principles. The company is actively recycling and reusing waste and materials, developing second lives for electric vehicle batteries, removing single-use plastic items from its operations, and recovering and reforming aluminum from used vehicles for new models. This approach not only reduces the need for virgin materials but also significantly lowers energy consumption in the production of recycled aluminum compared to new aluminum.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Achieving net zero carbon emissions across supply chain, products, and operations by 2039
    • All Jaguar and Land Rover nameplates to be available in pure electric form by the end of the decade
    • Reducing greenhouse gas emissions across its own operations by 46 per cent, and 54 per cent per vehicle across its value chain, by 2030

Nat Geo Wild

 90 64

Environmental protection

National Geographic is deeply committed to environmental protection and sustainability, integrating these principles into its brand ethos, storytelling, products, and nonprofit work. The organization focuses on combating climate change, resource depletion, pollution, and social inequities through conscious choices regarding the creation, use, and disposal of its products, experiences, and supplies. National Geographic evaluates the social and environmental impacts of its products, activations, and promotions, ensuring that any collaboration aligns with its commitment to social and environmental principles. This includes minimizing the use of toxic materials and finite natural resources, prioritizing durability, reparability, and recyclability, and eliminating pollutants and unrecoverable waste. National Geographic also emphasizes the importance of sourcing materials that are certified to be sustainably harvested or manufactured and ensures that no products are made from threatened or endangered species. The organization supports sustainable paper sourcing, aiming for 100% of the fiber used in its branded print products to be certified by recognized forestry certifications. Additionally, National Geographic is committed to minimizing negative environmental impacts and greenhouse gas emissions by seeking local, organic, and sustainably sourced resources, using recycled and recyclable content when possible, and minimizing waste of energy, water, food, and other resources. The organization also prioritizes clean manufacturing practices and packaging that follows the philosophy of reduce, reuse, and recycle. In terms of transportation, National Geographic aims to reduce unnecessary emissions by sourcing locally and prioritizing lower emission transportation options.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

National Geographic believes that work should be human-centered, ensuring that the manufacture of products does not sacrifice the health and safety of workforces, consumers, or communities. The organization is committed to addressing equity of impact throughout the value chain for all stakeholders, making efforts to understand the differential impact of its actions on various identities and communities. National Geographic aims to create positive social, economic, and environmental impacts without perpetuating negative burdens on minoritized and/or less affluent communities. This includes diverse input, local stakeholder engagement, and consideration of community concerns from the initial concept through decisions on labor, procurement, manufacturing, marketing, distribution, use, and disposal. National Geographic also emphasizes product and employee safety, requiring business collaborations to comply with all applicable local laws and regulations for product and employee safety in the countries where they operate. The organization supports the 10 Principles of the United Nations Global Compact, ensuring that all National Geographic-branded activities, products, and services created by NGP/Disney and its licensees meet these standards.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

National Geographic requires that no National Geographic-branded products are made from threatened, endangered, or illegally sourced or imported animals, plants, or forest products. The organization strives to ensure that no animals, plants, or forest products are used when their use is questionable from an ethical or conservation standpoint. National Geographic-branded interactions with animals must adhere to conservation status requirements, address ethical or conservation concerns, be responsible in the display of natural behaviors, minimize handling of wild animals, not disturb wild animals or habitats, not promote or encourage the keeping of exotic animals as pets, and ensure that no animals are used for testing of any National Geographic-branded products or services. This aligns with the Disney Live Animals in Entertainment policy, which includes monitoring for partnersâ compliance with these guidelines.

sources: 1

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Programme for the Endorsement of Forest Certification (PEFC)
    • Forest Stewardship Council (FSC)
    • Sustainable Forestry Initiative (SFI)
    • American Tree Farm System (ATFS)
  • Commitments
    • Aiming for 100% of the fiber used in National Geographic-branded print products to be certified by recognized forestry certifications

Crown Royal

 90 53

Environmental protection

Crown Royal, under its parent company Diageo, is making significant strides in environmental protection through the establishment of a new carbon-neutral distillery in Canada. This facility, representing a CAD$245 million investment, is designed to produce up to 20 million litres of absolute alcohol annually while operating on 100% renewable energy. The distillery's design incorporates resource efficiency technologies to ensure zero waste to landfill from all direct operations. This initiative is part of Diageo's broader "Society 2030: Spirit of Progress" sustainability action plan, aiming for net-zero carbon emissions across its direct operations by 2030. Additionally, Diageo has committed to transitioning its Valleyfield manufacturing site in Quebec to carbon neutrality by 2025 and aims to achieve net-zero carbon across its entire supply chain by 2050, with an interim goal of a 50% reduction by 2030. These efforts underscore Crown Royal's commitment to environmental sustainability and its role in Diageo's global strategy to combat climate change.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Nothing found

    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Transitioning the Valleyfield manufacturing site to carbon neutrality by 2025
    • Achieving net-zero carbon emissions across direct operations by 2030
    • Harnessing 100% renewable energy for direct operations by 2030
    • Achieving net-zero carbon across the entire supply chain by 2050, with an interim milestone of a 50% reduction by 2030

CarMax

 90 44

Environmental protection

CarMax has taken significant steps towards environmental protection, particularly in the area of climate change mitigation. The company has initiated an intensive process to identify and align on climate-related risks and opportunities, enhancing disclosure and improving management for long-term planning. This initiative is in line with the recommendations of the Task Force on Climate-Related Financial Disclosures (TCFD). CarMax has also finalized its greenhouse gas reduction roadmap, aiming to reduce Scope 1 and Scope 2 greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2025 compared to the 2018 baseline. Progress towards this goal is evident, with a reduction of more than 10% in greenhouse gas emissions already achieved by 2022. Furthermore, CarMax is focusing on becoming the leading retailer of used electric vehicles (EVs), improving its ability to recondition a broader range of hybrid and EV models, and enhancing educational content for first-time EV and hybrid vehicle owners through its subsidiary Edmunds and on CarMax.com.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

CarMax has made strides in workforce inclusivity and diversity. The company increased its ethnic and racial diversity in leadership positions from 29% in FY22 to 30.7% in FY23, and female representation in leadership positions from 23.4% to 24.2% over the same period. Additionally, CarMax has formalized its supplier diversity plan with a multi-year roadmap to ensure vendors have equal opportunities to do business with the company. These efforts are part of CarMax's broader commitment to diversity and inclusion, which is also reflected in the embedding of several ESG metrics, including greenhouse gas reduction and diversity and inclusion training goals, into its Annual Incentive Bonus Plan.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Reduce Scope 1 and Scope 2 greenhouse gas emissions by 50% by 2025 compared to the 2018 baseline

Amazon Fire TV Stick

 90 55

Environmental protection

Amazon is actively working to make the Fire TV Stick and other devices more sustainable and environmentally friendly. The company has committed to investing in renewable energy sources, such as wind and solar farms, to match the energy use of its Echo, Fire TV, and Ring devices worldwide by 2025. This initiative is part of Amazon's broader goal to reduce the carbon footprint of its devices throughout their lifecycle, from production to disposal. Amazon aims for each generation of its devices to be more carbon-efficient than the last. Over 60% of devices in customers' homes had Low Power Mode by the end of 2022, a feature that reduces energy consumption. Additionally, Amazon has committed to making its device packaging 100% recyclable by 2023 and sources 100% of the wood fiber in its packaging from responsibly managed forests or recycled sources. The company incorporates recycled materials into many new devices, including up to 75% recycled plastic, up to 100% recycled yarn, up to 100% recycled aluminum, and up to 90% recycled magnesium, depending on the product. Amazon has also joined ChemFORWARD as a co-design partner to advance the move to safer chemistry by identifying harmful chemicals and safer alternatives ahead of regulations.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Invest in wind and solar farm capacity equal to the energy use of Echo, Fire TV, and Ring devices worldwide by 2025
    • Make Amazon device packaging 100% recyclable by 2023
    • Source 100% of the wood fiber in our packaging from responsibly managed forests or recycled sources

Comfort Suites

Icy Hot

 90 62

Environmental protection

Icy Hot, through its parent company Sanofi Consumer Healthcare North America, has made significant strides in environmental sustainability. The company has committed to eliminating 35 tons of plastic packaging annually by removing plastic windows from products like AllegraÂ® and NasacortÂ®, aiming to reduce the environmental footprint and increase packaging recyclability. Additionally, it has achieved a 77% reduction in operational (scopes 1 and 2) greenhouse gas emissions at its North American manufacturing site since 2019. This is part of a broader goal to reach carbon neutrality by 2030 and net-zero emissions by 2045. Furthermore, the company has transitioned its North American manufacturing and distribution site to be powered by 100% renewable electricity, with a target to extend this to all global manufacturing operations by 2025. These efforts underscore Icy Hot's commitment to environmental sustainability and its broader goal of contributing to a healthier planet.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Icy Hot, as part of Sanofi Consumer Healthcare North America, has demonstrated a commitment to social impact and worker welfare. The company has achieved 41% representation of women in senior leadership roles, with a goal to reach 50/50 gender parity in senior leadership positions by 2025. This initiative is part of a broader commitment to diversity and inclusion within the company. Additionally, through the "Comebaq Courts" initiative, Icy Hot and the Shaquille O'Neal Foundation are renovating basketball courts in under-resourced communities. This effort not only improves facilities but also fosters community engagement and promotes physical activity. Furthermore, the company has partnered with KidSport Canada to provide access to organized sports opportunities for Canadian youth facing socio-economic barriers. These actions reflect Icy Hot's dedication to improving worker welfare and contributing positively to communities.

sources: 1

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Certified B Corp
  • Commitments
    • Eliminate 35 tons of plastic packaging per year
    • Reduce operational greenhouse gas emissions by 77% since 2019
    • Power North American manufacturing and distribution site with 100% renewable electricity by 2025
    • Achieve 50/50 gender parity in senior leadership positions by 2025
    • Reach carbon neutrality by 2030 and net-zero emissions by 2045
    • Reach 5M people by 2030 through on-the-ground programs

Valvoline

 90 55

Environmental protection

Valvoline demonstrates a strong commitment to environmental protection through various initiatives and strategies aimed at reducing carbon emissions and enhancing sustainability. The company has been actively participating in the CDP Climate Change Survey, achieving a "B" score in 2022, which is considered above average globally and average in North America. This score reflects Valvoline's efforts in transparency, efficient operations, and research and development, particularly in areas such as business strategy, governance, value chain engagement, and emission reduction strategies. Valvoline's carbon reduction strategy is multifaceted, focusing on avoiding emissions, reducing emissions within its operations, and mitigating remaining emissions. Key activities include building on the Scope 3 emissions inventory, expanding Renewable Energy Certificate (REC) purchases, targeting carbon reductions at high-emitting sites, executing a power purchasing agreement (PPA) with Orsted for carbon offsets from a renewable energy wind farm, and reducing energy intensity through participation in the US Department of Energyâs Better Plant Program. In 2022, Valvoline's manufacturing and warehouse operations increased REC purchases by 13% over the previous year and committed to a long-term PPA to offset all of Valvolineâs Scope 2 electric carbon emissions in North America. The company also achieved a 21% reduction in carbon intensity emissions from its 2016 baseline and set a revised short-term goal to offset 50% of its combined Scope 1 and 2 facility emissions by 2025. Additionally, Valvoline joined the Gigaton Power Purchasing Agreement (GPPA) with Ãrstedâs Sunflower Wind Farm, contributing to the production of approximately 250,000 MWh of wind power annually.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • 20% reduction in U.S. manufacturing and warehousing energy intensity by 2029
    • 50% reduction in combined Scope 1 and 2 facility carbon emissions by 2025
    • 10% reduction in carbon intensity achieved by 2022

Ferrari

 90 53

Environmental protection

Ferrari is actively working towards reducing its environmental footprint with a clear commitment to achieving carbon neutrality by 2030. This ambitious goal is supported by several concrete actions, including the installation of new photovoltaic panels generating over 450 kWp and the establishment of a 1 MW fuel cell plant at their Maranello facilities. Ferrari's approach to environmental sustainability also involves a significant reduction in greenhouse gas emissions across various scopes by 2030: a 90% reduction in absolute terms for Scope 1 & 2 emissions, a 30% reduction per car for Scope 3 upstream emissions, and a 50% reduction per car for Scope 3 downstream emissions. The company's efforts and emissions for 2022 have been certified in compliance with ISO 14064-1, ensuring the reliability of their reported data. These initiatives demonstrate Ferrari's commitment to growing its business activities while maintaining its COâ emissions almost stable, reflecting a strong dedication to environmental stewardship.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Ferrari places a strong emphasis on being the employer of choice by providing an inclusive, educational, and inspiring work environment. This is evident in their investment in employee development, with over 79,000 hours of training provided to the companyâs employees in 2022, marking a 13% increase compared to 2021. Additionally, Ferrari's "Formula Benessere" program has facilitated more than 5,700 medical and specialist checkups for employees and 744 for children. The company has also been confirmed for the Equal-Salary Certificate in Italy and North America for the third consecutive year, underscoring its commitment to ensuring fair compensation and fostering a supportive and enriching workplace for all employees.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • ISO 14064-1
  • Commitments
    • Achieving carbon neutrality by 2030
    • Reducing Scope 1 & 2 emissions by 90% in absolute terms by 2030 vs. 2021
    • Reducing Scope 3 upstream emissions by 30% per car by 2030 vs. 2021
    • Reducing Scope 3 downstream emissions by 50% per car by 2030 vs. 2021

Nivea

 90 60

Environmental protection

Nivea is actively engaged in various sustainability initiatives aimed at reducing its environmental impact. The company is committed to using sustainably sourced raw materials, with a particular focus on ingredients that are renewable or self-regenerating. Nivea works with suppliers who share its commitment to the planet, ensuring they have the necessary certifications. The brand has adopted a packaging philosophy centered around "reduce, reuse, recycle," continuously evolving its production methods and packaging to save energy, raw materials, and reduce emissions. Nivea has also made strides in responsible sourcing, particularly with palm oil, by joining the Round Table on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) and the Forum for Sustainable Palm Oil (FONAP). The company aims to source all its palm (kernel) oil sustainably and has achieved significant milestones towards this goal. Additionally, Nivea has committed to reducing its CO2 footprint, with ambitious energy goals including a 70% reduction in energy-related CO2 emissions by 2025 from a 2014 baseline. The company has already made significant progress by switching all its facilities to renewable energy, except for plants in Mexico and Nigeria. Nivea has also achieved "zero waste to landfill" across its established production centers, recycling or incinerating all waste to create heat and electricity. In packaging, Nivea is working towards using more recycled materials and aims for all its packaging to be recyclable, compostable, or reusable by 2025. The company has taken steps to protect the oceans by phasing out microplastics from its products and complying with regulations to protect coral reefs from harmful UV filters.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Nivea ensures that everyone involved in creating its skincare products is treated with respect and care. The company has established a Code of Conduct for Suppliers, setting high standards for suppliers and subcontractors, which align with Nivea's own standards. This includes commitments to protecting human rights and not tolerating forced or child labor, corruption, or discrimination in its operations and supply chain. Nivea also assists its suppliers in establishing sustainable supply chains, viewing the protection of the planet as a collective responsibility.

sources: 1, 3

Animal welfare

Nivea does not use animals to test cosmetic products, a policy in place long before the EU directives regulating animal testing in cosmetics. The company is involved in developing and using alternative testing methods, such as in-vitro procedures, to assess the safety and effectiveness of products without animal testing. Nivea is also a leading research company working on the development and recognition of alternative methods and advocates for the worldwide acceptance of existing animal test-free alternative methods.

sources: 3

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Round Table on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO)
    • Forum for Sustainable Palm Oil (FONAP)
  • Commitments
    • 70% reduction in energy-related CO2 emissions by 2025 from a 2014 baseline
    • All packaging to be recyclable, compostable, or reusable by 2025
    • Zero waste to landfill achieved across established production centers
    • All Nivea rinse-off products to be free of any microplastics according to the United Nations Environmental Program definition by 2020

Serta

 90 55

Environmental protection

Serta has demonstrated a commitment to environmental sustainability through various initiatives in its product manufacturing and material selection. The company emphasizes the use of eco-friendly components in its mattresses, including 100% of its innersprings and box springs made from 95% post-industrial recycled steel. Additionally, Serta's Hospitality Grade Foundations incorporate recycled steel and wood frames sourced from Forest Stewardship Council-certified forests. The fabrics used in many of Serta's mattress covers meet the Oeko-Tex 100 standard, ensuring they are manufactured without harmful substances. Serta also utilizes a blend of natural and synthetic latex that is anti-microbial and allergen-resistant, alongside fire retardant barriers made primarily from cotton or other renewable fibers without harmful chemicals. The company's foams are produced without PBDE flame-retardants, CFCs, lead, mercury, prohibited phthalates, and other potentially harmful materials, with some product lines featuring foam with bio-based content. The iComfortECO line further highlights Serta's environmental efforts, featuring up to 70% sustainable materials, including plant-based foams and recycled fibers. This line includes products such as the CoolTempâ¢ Cover made from recycled plastic bottles and the Terra Fusionâ¢ Memory Foam made from 28% plant-based material, alongside a support system made with 85% recycled steel and a latex layer containing 20% natural latex in select models.

sources: 1, 2

Michelin

 89 63

Environmental protection

Michelin is deeply committed to minimizing its environmental footprint, a commitment that has been part of its core values for over three decades. The company has been pioneering in the tire industry with the launch of the "green" tire in 1992, demonstrating its ability to innovate for less environmental impact. Through its "All-Sustainable" approach, part of the "Michelin in Motion" strategy, Michelin has set ambitious objectives for 2030 and beyond, focusing on climate, biodiversity, and natural resources. The company employs a life cycle assessment (LCA) to analyze the environmental footprint of its products and services, evaluating sixteen environmental impacts across four major areas: health, climate change, use of fossil-derived resources, and biodiversity. By 2030, Michelin aims for all its products and services to be eco-designed, addressing the environmental impact throughout their life cycle. The company is also committed to accelerating the energy transition, optimizing resource usage by increasing the amount of renewable or recycled materials in its products, and engaging in projects to protect and restore flora and fauna.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Michelin aims to be a global benchmark in workplace safety, employee engagement, diversity and inclusion, and customer value creation. This commitment is part of its "All-Sustainable" approach, which seeks to balance human, economic, and environmental concerns. The company's strategy, "Michelin in Motion," includes objectives for 2030 that emphasize the importance of personal development and fulfillment for its employees as a key pillar of its growth model.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • All products and services will be eco-designed by 2030.
    • Accelerating the energy transition and adapting to climate-related risks.
    • Optimizing resource usage and increasing amounts of renewable or recycled materials in products.
    • Minimizing the impact of activities and engaging in projects to protect and restore flora and fauna.

Amtrak

 89 56

Environmental protection

Amtrak has been actively working towards reducing its environmental impact through various initiatives aimed at sustainability and carbon footprint reduction. Over the past decade, Amtrak has implemented new technologies and changed employee behaviors, resulting in a reduction of over 414,054 metric tons of CO2e. This reduction is equivalent to the emissions from 90,048 passenger vehicles driven for one year. Amtrak has also committed to achieving net-zero greenhouse gas emissions across its network by 2045, focusing on reducing environmental impacts from operations while ensuring safe transportation for people. Additionally, since 2010, Amtrak has reduced its greenhouse gas emissions by 20% and aims to double this reduction by 2030. Efforts to reach this goal include reducing reliance on fossil fuels and investing in energy-efficient fleet options, such as Charger locomotives and the new Acela fleet, which will begin operating on the Northeast Corridor in 2022. Amtrak also emphasizes educating customers on the environmental benefits of train travel as part of its strategy to further reduce greenhouse gas emissions. sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions across the Amtrak Network by 2045
    • Reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 40% by 2030

StarKist

 89 61

Environmental protection

StarKist has demonstrated a commitment to environmental protection through various sustainability initiatives and partnerships. The company is a founding member of the International Seafood Sustainability Foundation (ISSF), a global coalition that includes scientists, the tuna industry, and the World Wildlife Fund (WWF). This partnership focuses on the long-term conservation and sustainable use of tuna stocks, reducing bycatch, and promoting ecosystem health. StarKist's involvement with ISSF includes cooperating with regional fisheries management organizations and adopting scientific recommendations for sustainable fish stock management. Additionally, StarKist has committed to sourcing all of its tuna and salmon from sustainable sources, including suppliers that meet the Marine Stewardship Council (MSC) standard or are working toward certification, as well as those participating in comprehensive fishery improvement projects (FIPs). The company supports the recommendation from the IOTC Scientific Committee to reduce yellowfin catches in the Indian Ocean and is committed to reducing its annual sourcing of Indian Ocean origin yellowfin by 11% to support stock rebuilding efforts. Furthermore, StarKist has achieved a milestone by sourcing 100% of its purse seine tuna supply from ISSFâs ProActive Vessel Register (PVR) listed vessels and aims to increase purchases from longline vessels registered on the PVR.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

StarKist is committed to ensuring the welfare of its workers and those within its supply chain. The company has implemented the StarKist Code of Conduct, which outlines its commitment to safe and fair working environments. As a member of Sedex, StarKist is dedicated to improving ethical standards and working conditions within the supply chain. Sedex provides tools, services, and a community network to help companies improve their responsible and sustainable business practices. Additionally, StarKist is a member of the Seafood Task Force (STF), which has developed comprehensive standards regarding fair labor practices for the fishing industry. The company endeavors to ensure that its seafood suppliers acknowledge and comply with these standards, demonstrating its commitment to responsible sourcing and improving working conditions.

sources: 2

Animal welfare

StarKist has policies in place to promote the welfare of marine life. The company was the first to adopt a dolphin-safe policy in 1990, ensuring that its tuna is sourced without harm to dolphins. This policy reflects full compliance with the Dolphin Protection Consumer Information Act. Additionally, as a founding member of the ISSF, StarKist denounces the practice of shark finning and adheres to a strict policy against it. The company only purchases fish from vessel-owning companies that share its anti-finning principles and have a published policy prohibiting shark finning on board their vessels. This commitment extends to ensuring that all sharks must be landed with fins naturally attached if retained.

sources: 2

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Marine Stewardship Council (MSC)
  • Commitments
    • Sourcing 100% of tuna and salmon from sustainable sources
    • Supporting the reduction of yellowfin catches in the Indian Ocean to support stock rebuilding
    • Sourcing 100% of purse seine tuna supply from ISSFâs ProActive Vessel Register (PVR) listed vessels
    • Committing to an 11% reduction in annual sourcing of Indian Ocean origin yellowfin

Zales

 89 46

Environmental protection

Zales demonstrates a commitment to environmental protection through its responsible sourcing protocols. The company ensures that the diamonds it sells are 100% conflict-free, adhering to strict standards that prevent the financing of armed conflict and human rights violations around the world. This includes a focus on sourcing materials that do not contribute to conflict, with all global suppliers required to comply with Responsible Sourcing Protocols. These protocols are recognized by leading international organizations and aim to ensure that the sourcing of gold, tin, tungsten, and tantalum does not contribute to conflict anywhere in the world. Additionally, Zales, through its parent company Signet Jewelers, is a founding and certified member of the Responsible Jewellery Council (RJC), an organization committed to promoting ethical, human rights, social, and environmental practices throughout the jewelry supply chain.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Zales places a strong emphasis on worker welfare within its supply chain. The company's suppliers are required to respect the Fundamental Conventions of the International Labour Organization and the UN Declaration of Human Rights. Zales is proactive in its efforts to support safe labor practices and create thriving communities. One notable initiative is its work with the Diamond Development Initiative, which focuses on bringing education to children in mining communities through the "Sending Schools to Kids" initiative. This program takes children from the mine to the classroom, providing them with uniforms, school materials, and daily meals. Furthermore, Zales supports Diamonds Do Good, a mission that enriches the lives of people in communities along the diamond supply chain by funding educational programs that develop and empower people in natural diamond communities.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Founding and certified member of the Responsible Jewellery Council (RJC)
  • Commitments
    • 100% conflict-free diamonds
    • Adherence to Responsible Sourcing Protocols recognized by leading international organizations

Tiffany & Co.

 89 52

Environmental protection

Tiffany & Co. has made significant strides in environmental protection, focusing on climate change and conservation. The company has pledged to achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions across its operations and supply chain by 2040, aligning with the Science Based Targets initiative (SBTi). To reach this ambitious goal, Tiffany & Co. has set a near-term target for 2030, aiming to reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 70% and Scope 3 emissions by 40%. This involves deep emission cuts across sourcing raw materials, engaging with suppliers, manufacturing, transportation, retail operations, and employee travel.

In addition to emission reduction, Tiffany & Co. is committed to sustainable building practices. Over 12% of their floor area was LEED Silver certified or above in 2022, with a goal to increase this to at least 30% by 2025. The company is also working towards eliminating all single-use plastic by 2025 and has already made its iconic packaging from more than 65% recycled content.

Furthermore, Tiffany & Co. invests in nature-based solutions to protect biodiversity and empower communities. A notable initiative is their investment in conserving and restoring 4,000 square kilometers of critical ecosystems in Kenyaâs Chyulu Hills, which will help reduce carbon emissions and support local communities.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Tiffany & Co. is actively involved in mentoring and supporting the next generation of leaders, particularly focusing on young women and gender-expansive youth of color through their partnership with The Lower Eastside Girls Club. This initiative is part of their broader commitment to diversity, equity, and inclusion, aiming to empower underrepresented communities and foster a more inclusive environment both within and outside the company.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Leadership in Energy and Environmental Design (LEED) Silver or above
  • Commitments
    • Achieve net-zero greenhouse gas emissions by 2040
    • Reduce Scope 1 and 2 emissions by 70% and Scope 3 emissions by 40% by 2030
    • Eliminate all single-use plastic by 2025
    • Have at least 30% of floor area LEED Silver certified or above by 2025

Build-A-Bear Workshop

 89 58

Environmental protection

Build-A-Bear Workshop has introduced an environmentally friendly product, Yew Yew the GREENZYS Panda, whose fur is made of soy. This product was launched in alignment with Earth Day and National Arbor Day celebrations. For each purchase of Yew Yew the GREENZYS Panda, Build-A-Bear Workshop commits to planting a tree in honor of the customer through the Arbor Day Foundation. This initiative not only promotes green living but also educates young customers on eco-friendly practices. The character of Yew Yew the GREENZYS Panda is designed to embody the principles of green living, such as preventing erosion and creating oxygen through bamboo growth. This effort is part of Build-A-Bear Workshop's broader mission to entertain and educate children about the importance of conservation, recycling, reusing, and replanting, with the hope that these practices become lifelong habits.

sources: 1

Pantene

 89 56

Environmental protection

Pantene is actively working towards reducing its environmental impact, particularly in the area of plastic usage and waste. The brand has set ambitious goals to address the environmental challenges posed by virgin plastic. By 2025, Pantene aims to reduce its virgin plastic usage by 50%, which is expected to avoid the use of 300,000 tons of virgin petroleum plastic. To achieve this, Pantene is focusing on making all its packaging 100% recyclable and continuously innovating with recycled plastic (PCR), refillable, and reusable packages. Additionally, the brand is striving for circular solutions to reduce its supply chain footprint. This includes using 100% renewable electricity, cutting greenhouse gas emissions in half at its sites, delivering a 35% increase in water efficiency, and using water from circular sources. Pantene is also advancing significant supply chain partnerships to drive circularity on climate, water, or waste and is committed to researching and seeking better alternatives to ensure a livable planet for future generations. Furthermore, Pantene has joined the Loop waste-free shopping initiative by TerraCycle to prevent single-use waste from ending up in the oceans. Through Loop, customers can purchase environmentally-friendly products in durable aluminum packaging, which is then collected from their doorstep to be cleaned, refilled, and reused.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Pantene has declared itself as cruelty-free, indicating a commitment to not conducting animal testing on their products. This stance is part of the brand's broader commitment to honesty and quality in their operations.

sources: 1

Transparency

  • Certifications

    • Cruelty-Free

  • Commitments

    • Reduce virgin plastic usage by 50% by 2025
    • Make all packaging 100% recyclable
    • Use 100% renewable electricity & cut GHG emissions in half at Pantene sites
    • Deliver a 35% increase in water efficiency & use water from circular sources

Keurig

 89 58

Environmental protection

Keurig is actively working towards a sustainable future with a focus on packaging, natural resource use, supply chain sustainability, and employee and community wellness. The company has set ambitious goals for 2025, including ensuring 100% of its packaging is recyclable or compostable, using 30% post-consumer recycled materials in all packaging, achieving zero waste to landfill from its operations, and sourcing 100% of its electricity from renewable energy sources. Keurig has developed a recyclable K-CupÂ® pod made from polypropylene #5 plastic, chosen for its high reusability and potential for a second life in products such as auto parts and outdoor furniture. This initiative is part of Keurig's broader effort to close the loop on waste and contribute to a circular economy. Additionally, the company's Grounds to Grow Onâ¢ program offers a recycling and composting solution for office K-CupÂ® pods, ensuring that 75% by weight is composted and the remaining 25% is recycled, with the goal of sending zero waste to landfills.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Keurig is committed to ensuring the welfare of workers throughout its supply chain. The company adheres to a Supplier Code of Conduct that mandates ethical and sustainable practices, protecting the rights and safety of laborers. Keurig requires its brewers and appliances to meet strict social, environmental, and ethical manufacturing standards. Furthermore, Keurig has been the largest Fair Trade coffee purchaser in the world since 2010, ensuring that farmers receive above-market pay, are protected from labor abuse, and can build stable farming businesses. This commitment to responsible sourcing is part of Keurig's broader strategy to support the farming communities it works with, promoting long-term sustainability and high-quality coffee and tea availability for future generations.

sources: 1

    • Zero waste from operations will be sent to landfills by 2025
    • 100% of electricity will come from renewable energy sources by 2025

Pedigree

 89 47

Environmental protection

Pedigree, as part of Mars, Incorporated, is actively involved in efforts to protect the environment through various initiatives. One of the key areas of focus is the reduction of carbon footprint and the redesigning of packaging for circularity. Pedigree has made significant strides in reducing waste and promoting sustainable packaging solutions. For instance, Pedigree Schmackos has achieved a reduction of 23 tons of plastic and 60 tons of paper in its sachets and cases, which translates to a 12% reduction in plastic usage and a 36% reduction in paper. Additionally, Mars, Incorporated has launched alternative protein sources such as Lovebugâ¢, the first 100% insect-based cat food in the UK, which boasts a smaller environmental footprint compared to traditional protein sources. These efforts are part of Mars' broader Sustainable in a Generation Plan, aiming for 100% reusable, recyclable, or compostable packaging and promoting sustainable practices across its brands.

sources: 1

Pedigree, through its parent company Mars, Incorporated, is involved in initiatives that not only benefit pets and pet owners but also contribute to a more sustainable world. The introduction of Lovebugâ¢, an insect-based cat food, represents a shift towards more sustainable and environmentally friendly protein sources. This product is developed to be nutritionally complete while having a significantly lower environmental impact compared to traditional protein sources. Such innovations indicate a commitment to promoting the health and welfare of animals by providing alternatives that reduce the environmental pawprint of pet food production.

Nordstrom

 89 55

Environmental protection

Nordstrom is actively working towards environmental sustainability by focusing on climate change, the environmental impact of products and services, and promoting a circular economy. The company has set ambitious goals for 2025, including establishing a science-based target to reduce Scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions, reducing single-use plastics in their value chain by 50%, ensuring 15% of their Nordstrom.com product assortment qualifies for Nordstrom for Good, and using preferred fibers for 50% of their primary raw materials. Additionally, Nordstrom aims to create channels to refurbish, reuse, resell, or donate 250 tons of clothing, take back 100 tons of beauty packaging to divert from landfills, and increase circular product design and development opportunities for Nordstrom Made products. The company has partnered with organizations like Clean Air Task Force, Fibershed, and FABSCRAP to support these initiatives and contribute to industry-wide circularity innovation.

Citgo

 89 42

Environmental Protection

CITGO is actively engaged in various environmental protection initiatives, focusing on energy efficiency, habitat restoration, and conservation. The company has partnered with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's ENERGY STAR program, aiming to enhance energy efficiency across its operations. This partnership is part of CITGO's broader commitment to operational excellence and sustainability, emphasizing the reduction of energy consumption and the conservation of natural resources. Additionally, CITGO has launched the "Caring for Our Coast" initiative, which began in 2014 as a series of projects dedicated to coastal conservation and restoration. This program has expanded to include protecting vulnerable coastal and inland habitats through educational and volunteer efforts. Furthermore, CITGO has demonstrated its commitment to preserving natural habitats by donating Petty's Island, a former site of CITGO operations, to the New Jersey Natural Lands Trust for use as an ecological preserve and educational facility. These efforts underscore CITGO's dedication to environmental stewardship and its role in promoting sustainability and conservation.

Allegra

 89 48

Environmental protection

Allegra has initiated several measures to reduce its environmental impact, focusing on ingredients, packaging, manufacturing, and disposal processes. The company emphasizes the use of Fexofenadine, a second-generation non-sedating antihistamine, highlighting its commitment to transparency by providing a comprehensive list of ingredients for each product. In terms of packaging, Allegra aims to use recycled or FSC certified materials for its cartons and leaflets by the end of 2023, with a goal to source all paper from sustainable sources by 2025. Some US Allegra products already use SFI certified cartons. In manufacturing, Allegra's Chattanooga, Tennessee site has achieved a 78% reduction in CO2 emissions across Scopes 1 and 2 since June 2023, with 100% of electricity sourced from renewable sources. The company aims for zero waste to landfill and a material recovery rate of 90% by 2025. Additionally, Allegra is working to reduce pharmaceutical residues in water streams and aims to reduce water withdrawals by 20% by 2030. Allegra has also partnered with TerraCycle to recycle old product packaging, turning waste into useful items like picnic tables and park benches.

Worker welfare

Animal welfare

    • Certified B Corp
  • Commitments
    • Use recycled or FSC certified materials for packaging by end of 2023
    • Source all paper from sustainable sources by 2025

    • Reduce CO2 emissions across Scopes 1 and 2 by 78% since June 2023
    • Source 100% of electricity from renewable sources
    • Reduce pharmaceutical residues in water streams
    • Reduce water withdrawals by 20% by 2030 vs 2019
    • Develop Biodiversity management plans by 2030 for manufacturing sites in sensitive areas

Suzuki Cars

 89 38

Environmental protection

Suzuki Motor Corporation is actively working towards reducing its environmental impact through various initiatives. The company is set to launch its first global electric vehicle in 2025, the eVX concept, which is part of Suzuki's commitment to innovation and sustainability. This electric vehicle, designed with a 60kWh battery capable of up to 550km range, represents a significant step towards eco-friendly transportation. Additionally, Suzuki's Global Growth Strategy for FY2030 emphasizes the expansion of eco-friendly models, including electric vehicles, as a key focus area. The company is also committed to reducing its carbon footprint by introducing new eco-friendly technologies and implementing energy-saving measures in its operations. This aligns with Suzuki's broader goal of addressing global warming and promoting sustainable business practices.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Suzuki Motor Corporation is involved in various initiatives aimed at ensuring worker welfare. The company's efforts include focusing on employee relations, safety and health, workforce diversity, and an education system for its employees. Additionally, Suzuki is committed to maintaining supply chain labor standards, which includes addressing issues such as child labor. These initiatives are part of Suzuki's broader social responsibility efforts, which also encompass engagement with local communities and efforts by domestic plants & R&D centers, as well as domestic and overseas sales distributors.

sources: 1

Sargento

 89 65

Environmental protection

Sargento demonstrates a commitment to environmental protection through various initiatives aimed at good stewardship of natural resources. The company focuses on using energy and water efficiently during its operations to minimize its environmental footprint. Additionally, Sargento is dedicated to waste minimization, working diligently to reduce waste in all forms throughout its processes. In terms of packaging, the company sources materials that not only ensure the highest levels of product quality but also aim to lessen environmental impacts. Furthermore, Sargento is a proud partner of How2Recycle, indicating its commitment to promoting recycling and reducing waste. These efforts reflect Sargento's dedication to sustainability and environmental responsibility.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Sargento places a strong emphasis on worker welfare, as evidenced by its comprehensive approach to supporting employees' overall wellbeing. This approach includes physical, mental, financial, spiritual, social, and emotional aspects, ensuring a holistic support system for its workforce. The company also encourages volunteering, providing opportunities for employees to give back to the community and get involved in charitable efforts. These efforts are focused on hunger, affordable housing, and education, demonstrating Sargento's commitment to improving the communities where its employees live and work. Additionally, Sargento advocates for the industry by sharing knowledge and expertise, further supporting the welfare of its workers and the broader community.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Sargento is committed to the ethical treatment of animals, partnering only with suppliers who share this commitment. The company ensures responsible sourcing by carefully vetting its suppliers, maintaining standards for food safety and quality that include the welfare of animals. This commitment to animal welfare is part of Sargento's broader efforts to ensure ethical sourcing and sustainability in its product offerings.

Nerf

 89 64

Environmental protection

Hasbro, the parent company of Nerf, has implemented a comprehensive Climate Action Plan aimed at reducing its carbon footprint and enhancing climate resilience. This plan is divided into two parts: the first focuses on reducing Greenhouse Gases (GHGs), while the second addresses climate risk and resilience, including the potential financial impacts of climate change on the business. A significant initiative under this plan is Hasbro's commitment to the Science-Based Target initiative (SBTi) and the Paris Agreement, aiming to limit global warming to 1.5Â°C. As of June 2023, SBTi approved Hasbro's near-term science-based emission reduction target, committing to reduce absolute Scope 1 and 2 GHG emissions by 47.5% and Scope 3 GHG emissions by 42% by 2030 from a 2020 base year. Additionally, Hasbro aims to reduce absolute Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions by 90% by 2050, aligning with reaching net-zero emissions.

Hasbro's Sustainability Center of Excellence drives the company's Environmental Blueprint, focusing on Design for the Environment, Sustainable Supply Chain & Production, and Facilities & Culture. The company is also dedicated to researching alternative materials to improve the sustainability of its products and packaging, ensuring their safety and durability. Hasbro's Forest Derived Materials Policy guides procurement decisions to support environmental sustainability, including protecting endangered forests and promoting sustainable forest management.

In terms of sustainable products and packaging, Hasbro has introduced several initiatives, such as eliminating wire ties from packaging, adding How2RecycleÂ® labeling, eliminating Styrofoam in new products, and using recycled or sustainably sourced paper. The company has also launched products like the Nerf Super Soaker CP30-AP, XP50-AP, and XP100-AP, utilizing more sustainable materials, including plant-based or recycled plastics and FSCÂ®-certified materials. Furthermore, Hasbro's Toy Recycling Program, in partnership with TerraCycleÂ®, offers consumers a sustainable option to recycle their toys and games, diverting over 45,000 pounds of waste from landfills since its inception.

sources: 1

    • Reduce absolute Scope 1, 2, and 3 GHG emissions by 90% by 2050 from a 2020 base year

Royal Caribbean Cruises

 89 42

Environmental protection

Royal Caribbean Cruises has implemented several initiatives to protect the environment and promote sustainability. The company is committed to decarbonization through innovation, collaborative partnerships, and a transition to cleaner fuels, smarter technologies, and improved energy efficiencies. They have set a short-term target to reduce carbon intensity by double digits by 2025 as part of their Destination Net Zero journey. Additionally, Royal Caribbean has opened the worldâs first net-zero cruise terminal in Galveston, Texas, and introduced the Blue Green Promiseâ  to support ocean communities around the world. Their sustainable practices include conserving energy with features like LED and fluorescent lights, using liquefied natural gas (LNG) as the cleanest-burning marine fuel, and implementing fuel cell technology. The company also focuses on water conservation, producing up to 90% of the freshwater used onboard through desalination and reverse osmosis systems, and creatively repurposing water for various uses. Waste management efforts include equipping ships to be landfill-free, reducing single-use plastics by 60%, and reducing food waste by 24% through the Win on Waste project. These initiatives demonstrate Royal Caribbean's commitment to protecting the oceans and environment for future generations.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Royal Caribbean Cruises is dedicated to fostering human rights and being an employer of choice. The company treats its employees, suppliers, and the communities in which it operates with dignity and respect. They seek feedback from guests, employees, and communities to inform their practices related to health, wellbeing, safety, and security. This approach ensures that Royal Caribbean continues to deliver unforgettable cruise experiences while prioritizing the welfare of its workers. The company's commitment to human rights and ethical treatment is embedded within its operations, demonstrating a dedication to creating a positive and respectful working environment for all.

sources: 1
