British Airways

 82 42

Environmental protection

British Airways is actively working towards reducing its environmental impact through a series of initiatives aimed at achieving net zero carbon emissions by 2050. The airline has committed to improving operational efficiency, investing in more fuel-efficient aircraft, and progressively introducing sustainable aviation fuels (SAF) using waste feedstocks. In the medium to long term, British Airways is focusing on the development and scale-up of SAF and exploring new technologies such as zero emissions hydrogen-powered aircraft and carbon capture technology. The airline is flying more fuel-efficient aircraft, including A350s, 787s, A320, and A321neos, which are up to 40% more fuel-efficient than the aircraft they replace. British Airways is also investing in first-of-a-kind SAF plants in the UK and the US to increase the availability of SAF. Additionally, the airline has collaborated with bp to source enough SAF for all its flights between London, Glasgow, and Edinburgh during the UKâs COP26 climate change summit, significantly reducing lifecycle emissions. British Airways is also offsetting carbon emissions on all its flights within the UK and has introduced an online platform, CO2llaborate, allowing customers to purchase SAF or carbon removal credits directly from their seats while onboard. The airline has introduced initiatives to improve sustainability in the air and on the ground, such as switching from diesel to renewably powered electric pushback vehicles and making its inflight magazine and flight manuals digital. British Airways has partnered with the Woodland Trust and Print Releaf to replant its paper footprint generated in the production of onboard paper products.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

British Airways is committed to creating a great place for people to work by fostering a diverse and inclusive workplace. The airline emphasizes the importance of a sense of wellbeing and belonging, enabling its employees to thrive. This commitment is reflected in its efforts to ensure diversity and inclusion across the airline, recognizing the value of different perspectives, backgrounds, and experiences. British Airways is actively working on various programmes and initiatives to fulfill its commitments to diversity and inclusion, aiming to reflect the diversity of the world it operates in.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

British Airways is committed to protecting wildlife and adheres to the rules set out by the 1973 Convention on International Trade in Endangered Species (CITES) treaty. The airline is a signatory to the United for Wildlife Transport Taskforce, also known as the Buckingham Palace Declaration, committing to share credible intelligence about high-risk routes and methods of transportation, develop a secure system for passing information about suspected illegal wildlife trade to relevant authorities, and refuse to accept or ship cargo suspected of containing illegal wildlife and their products. Additionally, British Airways has partnered with the Born Free Foundation to ensure that it never promotes the captivity of wild animals and discourages its hotel partners from doing so. This partnership also supports the creation of a new sanctuary space for rescued wild animals and Born Freeâs Raise the Red Flag initiative, which allows the public to report captive wild animal welfare concerns.

sources: 1

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • IATA Environmental Assessment (IEnvA) Stage 2
  • Commitments
    • Achieving net zero carbon emissions by 2050
    • Powering 10% of flights with sustainable aviation fuel by 2030

Acer

 82 48

Environmental protection

Acer is actively engaged in various environmental protection initiatives, focusing on climate strategy, renewable energy, and circular economy principles. The company has committed to using 100% renewable electricity by 2035 and aims to achieve net zero emissions by 2050. Acer's approach to circular economy includes sustainable design, the use of recycled materials, and reducing plastic packaging, with a specific goal to incorporate 20-30% of post-consumer recycled (PCR) plastics content in computers and displays. Additionally, Acer has made significant strides in reducing the environmental impact of its products through innovative design and effective material use, aiming for a balance between product management and environmental protection. The company has also been recognized for its environmental efforts, achieving a leadership level A- rating from CDP for climate change. Acer's commitment to environmental sustainability is further evidenced by its goal to reach 60% renewable electricity usage and a 45% reduction in average computer energy consumption by 2025 compared to 2016. Moreover, 80% of Acer's critical suppliers have committed to RE100 or set carbon reduction Science-Based Targets (SBTs).

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Acer places a high priority on worker welfare, ensuring fair treatment, respect, and a safe and healthy working environment for its employees. The company engages its workforce in environmental protection and social participation through Project Humanity, with over 90% of employees participating. Additionally, Acer focuses on IT education and employee engagement, with 80% of its global employees actively engaged in their work. This commitment to creating an inclusive workplace and society is part of Acer's broader strategy to use its resources and influence for community welfare and progress.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • CDP Climate Change Leadership Level A-
  • Commitments
    • 100% renewable electricity by 2035
    • Net zero emissions by 2050
    • 60% renewable electricity usage
    • 45% reduction in average computer energy consumption by 2025 compared to 2016
    • 80% of critical suppliers committed to RE100 or set carbon reduction SBTs
    • 20-30% of PCR plastics content in computers and displays

Sheraton

 82 49

Environmental protection

Sheraton's sustainability efforts focus on reducing their environmental footprint through various initiatives aimed at conserving resources and enhancing efficiency. At the Sheraton Norfolk Waterside Hotel, efforts include responsible and local sourcing, recycling to reduce waste, and water conservation through water reclaim systems. Guest rooms are equipped with LED lighting, low-flow water fixtures, and smart thermostats. Guests are encouraged to opt out of daily housekeeping to reduce energy use, and the plastic from bathroom toiletries is recycled. The hotel employs smart building automation systems to monitor and manage energy and water use, alongside high-efficiency boilers, chillers, variable frequency drives for energy savings, kitchen hood controls, and other innovations for responsible operation.

The Sheraton Cascais Resort has also implemented several measures to minimize its environmental impact. These include the use of LEDs, individual electricity and water meters, a dashboard by room to reduce energy consumption, HVAC systems that utilize outside temperatures for air conditioning, automatic AC shutoff when windows are opened, sensor-controlled property lighting, low-capacity toilet flushes, thermal glass windows, external charging stations for electric vehicles, and the promotion of electric bicycles. The resort is committed to recycling all waste produced and uses environmentally certified paper. Additionally, the Chef's Garden at the resort allows for the cultivation of a variety of vegetables and herbs with a self-irrigation system that saves water and produces more efficiently.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Nothing found

New York Life

 82 39

Environmental protection

New York Life has outlined a comprehensive approach to environmental sustainability, focusing on reducing its operational impact and promoting responsible investment practices. The company has committed to reducing its operational Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions by 30% by 2030, using a 2019 baseline. Efforts to achieve this goal include reducing energy consumption in buildings and data centers, employing electronic communication to minimize paper use, and adhering to recycling guidelines. New York Life also emphasizes the importance of using Forest Stewardship Council (FSC) certified paper, reducing corporate printing, and switching to biodegradable or reusable materials in cafeterias. The company is actively measuring and monitoring key performance indicators related to environmental performance, such as energy consumption, water usage, waste diversion, and greenhouse gas emissions. Additionally, New York Life is engaging its stakeholders on environmental sustainability issues and reporting progress through annual corporate responsibility reports and other communications. The company's investment arm incorporates environmental, social, and governance (ESG) factors, including climate change, into its investment analysis and has integrated ESG and resilience into its real estate investment processes. New York Life Investments aligns its program with industry standards, including GRESB and UN PRI, and evaluates new real estate acquisitions for climate-related risks.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

New York Life demonstrates a commitment to worker welfare through various initiatives focused on diversity, equity, and inclusion (DE&I), corporate ethics, and employee engagement. The company boasts a workforce where 59% are women, and 50% of its Board of Directors consists of women and people of color. Furthermore, 42% of its workforce are people of color. New York Life fosters a diverse and inclusive work environment where employees are encouraged to bring their authentic selves to work. The company's core value of Integrity is central to its business, ensuring ethical conduct across all operations. New York Life also has an Ethics Hotline, managed by an independent third party, allowing for the reporting of unethical or unlawful behavior. Additionally, the company's short-term incentive program includes consideration of strategic, non-financial ESG indicators, tracking progress in areas such as diversity representation, client experience, community and employee engagement, philanthropic giving, and volunteerism.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Reduce operational Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions 30% by 2030, from a 2019 baseline

Milwaukee

 82 49

Environmental protection

Milwaukee has set a significant environmental goal aiming for a 60% reduction in tCO2e across its operations by 2030. The company is making strides towards this target by implementing various sustainability initiatives. For instance, over 90% of the electricity used in its Wisconsin operations comes from renewable sources, amounting to nearly 30,000,000 kWh/year in renewable energy. Similarly, in Mississippi, Milwaukee has partnered with the Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) to utilize 30,000,000 kWh of certified renewable energy generated through wind farms, offsetting 100% of the electricity used in its distribution centers. Additionally, Milwaukee has partnered with Call2Recycle to help recycle more than 8 million pounds of batteries annually. The company is also transitioning to 100% energy-efficient LED lighting across all facilities, with 70% completion so far. Efforts to reduce electricity consumption include solving compressed air leaks, saving nearly 500,000 kWh/year, and upgrading to high-efficiency HVAC equipment in half of its facilities. Moreover, Milwaukee is increasing recycling options in its plants, diverting more than 200,000 lbs of plastic stretch film from landfills annually.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Nothing found

  • Certifications

  • Commitments
    • Committing to a 60% reduction in tCO2e across operations by 2030

PediaSure

 82 50

Environmental protection

PediaSure, through its parent company Abbott, is committed to environmental protection as part of its Global Environment, Health, and Safety Policy. The company aims to reduce environmental emissions, lower the use of natural resources, and minimize waste destined for landfill. These efforts are part of a broader commitment to continuously improve the efficiency and sustainability of its business activities and products. Abbott's policy includes fostering a work environment that promotes employee health and productivity, ultimately aiming for a workplace free of injuries. The company also expects contractors to conform to regulatory requirements and meet applicable internal Environment, Health, and Safety (EHS) standards. Abbott has established meaningful goals and strategies for the enterprise and reports publicly on its progress towards achieving them. This commitment reflects Abbott's core values of Pioneering, Achieving, Caring, and Enduring, and applies to all operations and employees worldwide.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

PediaSure's Grow & Gain Organic product line uses milk from grass-fed cows, indicating a consideration for the quality and source of animal-derived ingredients. This choice is part of their effort to provide USDA-certified organic nutrition, which inherently includes higher animal welfare standards compared to conventional farming. The organic certification ensures that the milk comes from cows that have access to pasture, are fed organic feed, and are not treated with synthetic hormones or antibiotics, aligning with better animal welfare practices.

Dove Baby

 82 51

Environmental protection

Dove has launched several initiatives aimed at reducing its environmental impact, particularly in terms of plastic waste. The brand is committed to reducing its use of virgin plastic by 50% by 2025, aiming to save at least 9,000 tonnes of plastic annually. This commitment includes making the packaging for its iconic Beauty Bar plastic-free globally and launching 100% recycled plastic bottles across all its product ranges where technically feasible. Dove is also exploring more sustainable plastic choices for products where 100% recycled plastic is not currently an option, including caps and pumps. Additionally, Dove has introduced a reusable, refillable, stainless steel deodorant stick format called minimâ¢, which significantly reduces plastic use. In 2022, Dove launched a dilute-at-home body wash formula in the US, utilizing refill bottles made from recyclable and 100% recycled materials, further contributing to its efforts to reduce plastic waste.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Dove is proud to be PETA Approved, indicating that it does not test its products on animals. This certification is part of Dove's commitment to ethical sourcing and sustainability, ensuring that its products are cruelty-free. This aligns with Dove's broader mission to contribute to a healthy, thriving future for the planet while protecting it for future generations.

sources: 1

  • Commitments

Fujifilm

 82 50

Environmental protection

Fujifilm is actively engaged in reducing its environmental impact and contributing to the resolution of environmental issues. This commitment is part of its broader corporate social responsibility (CSR) strategy, which includes the Sustainable Value Plan 2030 (SVP2030). The SVP2030 outlines Fujifilm's targets for fiscal year 2030, aiming to lay the foundations for the company's business management strategies for sustainable growth. Fujifilm's environmental efforts are recognized by its inclusion in the CDP "A List" for leadership in climate action. Additionally, the company has set ambitious goals for reducing greenhouse gas emissions, validated as aligning with the "1.5Â°C goal" by the Science Based Targets (SBT) initiative. Fujifilm has also announced a Virtual Power Purchase Agreement to offset 100% of its North American electricity use with renewable energy, demonstrating its commitment to environmental responsibility.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Fujifilm has announced the Fujifilm Group Employee Wellness Declaration in September 2019, emphasizing the importance of employee health and wellness. This initiative sets target values across the group for priority issues, aiming to improve the health of its employees. Furthermore, Fujifilm has been recognized for its efforts in promoting a healthy workplace, winning the highest honor in the corporate HR category of the HR Awards 2023. These actions reflect Fujifilm's commitment to enhancing worker welfare and promoting social change where every person is motivated in the workplace.

Jameson

 82 48

Environmental protection

Jameson, under its parent company Irish Distillers, has initiated several measures to protect the environment, focusing on sustainable packaging solutions. The brand has emphasized the recyclability of its bottles, which are made using some amount of already recycled glass. Additionally, Jameson has made efforts to ensure that its 500ml plastic bottles and aluminum cans are recyclable, aligning with global recycling standards. The company has also taken steps to make its cardboard gift boxes 100% recyclable by removing all plastic inserts, facilitating easier recycling processes for consumers. Beyond packaging, Jameson has repurposed approximately 302,000 unused plastic cups from its inventory to create tote bags, combining 65% PET from these cups with 35% cotton, as part of moving away from single-use plastics in line with Pernod Ricard's sustainability goals.

Irish Distillers announced a significant step towards sustainability by committing to make all secondary packaging across its portfolio of Irish whiskeys recyclable, reusable, compostable, or removed by the end of 2025. This initiative includes the progressive removal of approximately 4 million gift boxes from the Jameson product range. The company is also applying Pernod Ricardâs circular making strategy, which encompasses the principles of Rethink, Reduce, Reuse, Recycle, and Respect, to its product lifecycle. Notable changes include the transition of Midleton Very Rare 2023 to a high-quality recyclable box, reducing fossil fuel emissions, greenhouse gas emissions, and water usage significantly compared to its previous wooden packaging. Jameson 18 Years and other premium offerings like Redbreast 21 and Redbreast 27 will also transition to fully recyclable secondary packaging by the end of 2025.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Nothing found

    • Removal of approximately 4 million gift boxes from the Jameson product range by the end of 2025
    • Transition of premium offerings to fully recyclable secondary packaging by the end of 2025

HSN

 82 37

Environmental protection

HSN, as part of its environmental commitment, has implemented several initiatives aimed at reducing its environmental impact and promoting sustainability. The company has focused on using biodegradable materials, specifically introducing packaging made from 50% recycled plastic and 100% biodegradable dosing scoops for its powder products. These efforts are part of HSN's broader goal to minimize plastic usage in packaging, considering the conservation needs of its food products. Additionally, HSN has adjusted packaging sizes to reduce unnecessary material, contributing to lower transport costs and carbon emissions. Recycling is integral to HSN's operations, with all containers used in its plant and offices being recycled. The company also emphasizes the importance of controlling the entire product development and production chain to ensure the recycling of all packaging left over from the process. HSN has partnered with the sustainable delivery company Paack to minimize environmental impact through decarbonization actions, including 100% zero-emission distribution and the use of electric vehicles. Furthermore, HSN has committed to becoming Carbon Net Zero by 2030 and has started including the FSC seal on its shipments to promote sustainable forest management. The company is also investing in renewable energy, specifically solar panels, to cover the energy needs of its production facilities and contribute excess energy to the electricity grid. Lastly, HSN is developing the BioSeries line, focusing on 100% natural products with ingredients sourced from organic farming and minimizing plastic use in packaging.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

HSN has demonstrated a commitment to worker welfare through its collaborations with various organizations aimed at supporting individuals with basic or specific unmet needs. The company has partnered with the Red Cross, Food Bank, FundaciÃ³n RaÃ­les, and FundaciÃ³n UAPO, among others, to improve the quality of life for people in different communities. These collaborations include different actions and activities, such as educational support, provision of breakfasts and snacks, leisure and free-time activities, and prevention and awareness workshops for children. HSN also supports the RaÃ­les Foundation by providing sports equipment and clothing for the foundation's basketball team, promoting the rights and well-being of people with disabilities. Additionally, HSN has initiated support for the UAPO Foundation, which works to provide comprehensive intervention for oncology patients, including physical exercise programs to improve their quality of life and recovery. These efforts reflect HSN's dedication to enhancing worker and community welfare through meaningful partnerships and support programs.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

  • Certifications
    • Verpackungsrecycling: Duales System Interserch
    • FSC seal
  • Commitments
    • Commitment to becoming Carbon Net Zero by 2030

    • Investment in renewable energy (solar panels) for all facilities

Winn-Dixie

 82 47

Environmental protection

Winn-Dixie, through its parent company Southeastern Grocers Inc. (SEG), has demonstrated a strong commitment to environmental stewardship and sustainability. In 2022, SEG made significant strides in fulfilling its environmental commitments and implementing sustainable improvements. This includes a focus on increasing sustainability for its Own Brand packaging by the end of 2028, with efforts to eliminate the use of polystyrene and ensure all packaging is either reusable, recyclable, or industrially compostable. Additionally, SEG aims to include an average of 30% post-consumer recycled material in all Own Brand packaging. The company has also committed to the guiding principles of The Five Freedoms of Animal Welfare to enhance its animal welfare policy and outlined policies to protect vital pollinator populations. Furthermore, SEG has partnered with Relocalize to pilot ice manufacturing in the worldâs first autonomous micro-factory, designed to reduce global greenhouse gas emissions, water waste, and plastic pollution. This initiative launched in March 2023 with the introduction of SE Grocers Party Cubes, a super-premium cubed ice made efficiently, locally, and on-demand for select Jacksonville locations. In celebration of Earth Day, SEG supported environmental causes and promoted sustainability through various actions, including donations to local organizations, partnering with Florida State Parks for design contests aimed at reducing single-use plastic bags, and implementing volunteer cleanup days for store teams.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Winn-Dixie, under SEG, has shown a commitment to community engagement and values-driven operations, which indirectly impacts worker welfare. In 2022, SEG and its charitable arm, the SEG Gives Foundation, donated over $700,000 and 14 million pounds of food to help alleviate hunger. Additionally, they donated $2.55 million to support crucial emergency assistance, disaster preparedness, and relief programs. SEG also donated more than $1.25 million to Folds of Honor, providing over 250 educational scholarships to the children and spouses of fallen and disabled military service members. Furthermore, SEG expanded its giving focus to support more causes dedicated to elevating belonging, inclusion, and diversity, allowing the grocer to make a larger impact within its communities. This includes the Romay Davis Belonging, Inclusion, and Diversity Grant Program, which presented 30 nonprofits with funds totaling $300,000 in its third year.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Winn-Dixie, through SEG, has committed to the guiding principles of The Five Freedoms of Animal Welfare to further enhance its animal welfare policy. This commitment is part of SEG's broader sustainability efforts and demonstrates the company's dedication to the betterment of animal welfare. Additionally, SEG has outlined policies to nurture and protect the planetâs vital pollinator populations, which is crucial for safeguarding food security now and for future generations.

sources: 1

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Increase sustainability for Own Brand packaging by the end of 2028, ensuring all packaging is either reusable, recyclable, or industrially compostable.
    • Include an average of 30% post-consumer recycled material in all Own Brand packaging.
    • Committed to the guiding principles of The Five Freedoms of Animal Welfare to enhance its animal welfare policy.
    • Outlined policies to protect vital pollinator populations.

AÃ©ropostale

 82 43

Environmental protection

AÃ©ropostale has taken significant steps to reduce its carbon footprint and protect the environment through the use of recycled materials in its clothing lines. The company has expanded its use of recycled cotton and recycled polyester fabrics, which are made from a mix of pre- and post-consumer waste. This initiative not only reduces air and water pollution but also decreases carbon emissions by avoiding the need for new petroleum in the production of recycled polyester. Additionally, the production of recycled polyester and recycled cotton requires far fewer resources than conventional materials, conserving water and energy. AÃ©ropostale also repurposes materials to prolong their lifespan and prevent them from ending up in landfills prematurely. Their responsible denim collection is manufactured with RepreveÂ® recycled polyester yarns made from plastic bottles, further reducing waste in landfills and conserving water and energy. Moreover, the company uses organically grown cotton, produced without harmful chemicals and in accordance with certified organic agriculture standards, which promotes water and air quality, energy conservation, agricultural biodiversity, and healthy soil. This approach has a lower environmental impact than traditional cotton-growing methods and benefits the long-term health of people and the planet.

Vizio

 82 51

Environmental protection

VIZIO has demonstrated a strong commitment to environmental protection through various initiatives aimed at reducing electronic waste and promoting sustainable practices. The company has successfully diverted over 360 million pounds of electronics from landfills by supporting more than 1,000 permanent electronic waste collection sites in the US and ensuring that used electronics are sent to third-party certified recyclers. VIZIO's e-waste recycling program not only helps in reducing landfill waste but also supports the creation of jobs in the circular economy. Additionally, VIZIO has achieved the Gold Tier Award Level in the EPA Sustainable Materials Management (SMM) Challenge, which requires participants to send at least 95% of all used electronics collected to a third-party certified recycler and to continually increase the total amount of used electronics collected for reuse and recycling. VIZIO is also an e-Stewards Enterprise Organization, further emphasizing its commitment to responsible electronic waste recycling and environmental protection. Moreover, VIZIO was one of the first companies to create mercury-free TVs, showcasing its dedication to developing eco-friendly products.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

VIZIO is committed to protecting the rights of its employees and those who manufacture its products and work in its supply chain. The company is a member of the Responsible Business Alliance (RBA), fully supporting the vision and mission of the RBA to develop a global electronics industry that creates sustainable value for workers, the environment, and business. By adhering to the RBA Code of Conduct, VIZIO commits to improving working and environmental conditions and encourages its suppliers to do the same. Additionally, VIZIO engages in verification activities to identify, assess, and manage the risks of human trafficking in its product supply chain, including annual risk assessments and independent third-party audits of direct suppliers. The company requires its direct suppliers to ensure compliance with all laws regarding slavery and human trafficking of the countries in which they are doing business, maintaining internal accountability procedures for employees and contractors failing to meet company standards regarding slavery and trafficking.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • e-Stewards Enterprise Organization
  • Commitments
    • Achieving Gold Tier in the EPA SMM Challenge
    • Membership in the Responsible Business Alliance (RBA)

Liz Claiborne

Stanley

 82 56

Environmental protection

Stanley is actively engaged in several initiatives aimed at protecting the environment. The company has made a commitment to prioritize recycled and upcycled materials in their manufacturing processes. Specifically, Stanley has set a goal to ensure that at least 50% of its stainless steel products are made from recycled materials by 2025. This initiative is part of their broader effort to create products that are durable and functional, reducing the need for disposable alternatives. Additionally, Stanley has taken significant steps to reduce its packaging waste. The company has eliminated most conventional plastic packaging and is working towards ensuring all paper packaging is made from certified sustainable or recycled content by the same year, 2025. In a notable effort to reduce plastic waste, Stanley stopped using conventional plastic bags for product shipping and delivery in 2021, opting instead for paper wraps. This change alone is expected to prevent more than 77 metric tons of plastic from being used each year. Furthermore, Stanley's product designs increasingly incorporate recycled materials, such as the use of ocean-bound recycled plastic in the lid of their Iceflowâ¢ Flip Straw Jug, and their Classic Perfect-Brew Pour Over, which eliminates the need for non-organic waste by foregoing filters.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Stanley demonstrates a commitment to community and worker welfare through its financial and volunteer contributions. The company donates more than 1% of its net income to causes that support nature conservation, sustainability, equitable and empowered access to the outdoors, and food security. In addition to financial contributions, Stanley also donates products and encourages its employees to volunteer their time. The company collaborates with values-driven organizations to create change within local communities. This approach not only benefits the environment but also supports the welfare of workers and communities by fostering a culture of giving back and sustainability.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications

    • Nothing found

  • Commitments

    • Making at least 50% of stainless steel products from recycled materials by 2025
    • Eliminating most conventional plastic packaging
    • Ensuring all paper packaging is certified sustainable or made from recycled content by 2025

Aston Martin

 82 51

Environmental protection

Aston Martin has embarked on a comprehensive sustainability strategy named Racing. Green., focusing on reducing its environmental impact and transitioning towards a more sustainable future. The company has committed to delivering its first Plug-In Hybrid Electric Vehicle (PHEV), the Valhalla, in 2024, followed by its first Battery Electric Vehicle (BEV) in 2025, with a goal to have a fully electrified sports car and SUV portfolio by 2030. Aston Martin aims to achieve net-zero manufacturing facilities by 2030 and extend this ambition across its supply chain by 2039. The company has also set targets to eliminate single-use plastic packaging waste from its manufacturing facilities by 2025, reduce water consumption in its manufacturing operations by 15% by the same year, and maximize the use of sustainable materials. Aston Martin has achieved carbon-neutral manufacturing at its Gaydon and St Athan facilities, marking a significant step towards its net-zero goals. The company has been powered by 100% renewable electricity since 2019 and is investing in renewable energy projects, including the installation of solar panels at its facilities. These efforts are part of Aston Martin's broader commitment to reducing CO2 emissions from its manufacturing processes and supply chain, as well as offsetting Scope 1 and Scope 2 emissions through verified projects.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Aston Martin is committed to investing in people and opportunities as part of its sustainability strategy. The company aims for world-class safety performance and is focused on delivering industry-leading apprenticeships and training programs. Aston Martin is building a more diverse and inclusive workplace, with targets to have women in 25% of leadership positions by 2025 and 30% by 2030. These efforts are part of Aston Martin's broader commitment to supporting communities and inspiring young people to pursue careers in manufacturing.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Carbon Trust certification for carbon neutrality in 2022 for Aston Martin Lagonda Ltd and Aston Martin Works Ltd in accordance with PAS 2060 3
  • Commitments
    • Delivery of Valhalla, the first Plug-In Hybrid Electric Vehicle (PHEV), in 2024 1
    • Launch of the first Battery Electric Vehicle (BEV) in 2025 1
    • Fully electrified sports car and SUV portfolio by 2030 1
    • Net-zero manufacturing facilities by 2030 1
    • Net-zero across the supply chain by 2039 1
    • Elimination of single-use plastic packaging waste from manufacturing facilities by 2025 1
    • 15% reduction in water consumption at manufacturing operations by 2025 1
    • Maximization of the use of sustainable materials 1
    • Women in 25% of leadership positions by 2025 and 30% by 2030 1

Versace

 82 42

Environmental protection

Versace has initiated several projects to minimize its environmental impact and promote sustainability. The brand has launched the Versace Upcycle collection for eco-conscious kids, made from upcycled unused production and recycled materials. Versace's Milan Headquarters and its new concept store in Bal Harbour, Miami, have achieved LEED certification, demonstrating a commitment to environmental sustainability in its operations. Additionally, Versace has created a sustainable dress for the Met Gala, showcasing its dedication to sustainable fashion practices. The brand has also committed to fur-free designs, aligning with ethical and environmental considerations. Versace is part of the Camera della Moda sustainability working group, aiming to improve the fashion industry's impact on the environment and society.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Versace emphasizes diversity and inclusion, considering it fundamental to its identity since its founding in 1978. The brand has expanded this vision to include biodiversity, aiming to protect and nourish all living things on Earth. Versace is committed to responsible sourcing, which includes ensuring that the materials used in its collections have a lower carbon footprint, use less water, create less waste, and support efforts to protect biodiversity. The brand actively engages within its supply chains to maintain rigorous social, ethical, and environmental standards, focusing on positively impacting the people involved in the production process. Versace has developed a social responsibility program to ensure rigorous standards in its supply chain, including health and safety, welfare, fair pay, human rights, forced labor, and discrimination protections.

sources: 1, 2

Animal welfare

Versace has publicly committed to going fur-free, stating, "Fur? I am out of that. I don't want to kill animals to make fashion." This decision reflects the brand's commitment to ethical fashion and animal welfare, aligning with broader industry trends towards more humane practices.

sources: 1

    • Commitment to fur-free designs

Wonderful Pistachios

 82 59

Environmental protection

Wonderful Pistachios has made significant strides in environmental sustainability, focusing on various aspects such as energy, water, waste, and packaging. The company has committed to powering all of its U.S. operations with 100% renewable electricity by 2025. In terms of water usage, they have achieved a 20% reduction in water used to grow each pound of pistachios through the introduction of innovative new rootstock. Waste management efforts have led to diverting 500 million pounds of material from landfills annually. Additionally, Wonderful Pistachios is transitioning to fully recycled plastic (rPET) bottles for FIJI Water and POM Wonderful by 2025, emphasizing their commitment to sustainable packaging solutions. These initiatives are part of a broader commitment to environmental stewardship and sustainability, as evidenced by their $400 million investment in sustainable agriculture and various sustainability programs and partnerships aimed at reversing climate change and promoting sustainable practices across their operations.

Bud Light Plainum

 82 35

Environmental protection

Bud Light Platinum, under its parent company Anheuser-Busch, has taken significant steps towards environmental sustainability. The brand achieved Climate Neutral Certification by measuring, offsetting last year's carbon emissions, and implementing plans to reduce future emissions. This certification, awarded by the nonprofit organization Climate Neutral, indicates that Bud Light Platinum has taken accountability for the greenhouse gas emissions generated in the production and operations of their goods or services. To further demonstrate their commitment to environmental protection, Bud Light Platinum has decided to feature the Climate Neutral certification on its packaging. Additionally, in collaboration with the League of Legends Championship Series (LCS), Bud Light Platinum offset 100% of the electricity used during the LCS Spring Finals in Houston, TX, with clean, renewable wind power sources. These actions are part of Bud Light's broader efforts to encourage environmental responsibility among consumers and partners, including joining the How2RecycleÂ® labeling program and conducting a zero-emissions beer delivery with Nikola Corporation and BYD Motors ahead of Super Bowl 56. These initiatives underscore Bud Light Platinum's commitment to becoming Anheuser-Buschâs first net-zero carbon footprint beer, aligning with the company's ambition to achieve net zero by 2040 through sustainability initiatives.

Johnsonville Sausage

 82 57

Environmental protection

Johnsonville Sausage has initiated several measures to reduce its environmental impact, particularly in its packaging processes. The company has transitioned to using an innovative polystyrene foam tray, named EVOKÂ®, for its fresh sausage products. This tray is notable for containing 25% recycled material, making Johnsonville the first national branded sausage leader to adopt this packaging in the U.S. The switch to EVOKÂ® packaging is expected to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by 15% across all its fresh meats, including a wide range of products from Fresh Bratwurst to Chicken Kabobs. Additionally, Johnsonville has implemented other environmental initiatives, such as a recycle and reuse program with its zipper spool vendor, which has prevented 50,000 pounds of waste from reaching landfills. The company also redesigned some of its polystyrene foam trays to use 6% less packaging material, resulting in an annual reduction of 120,000 pounds of material waste. These efforts are part of Johnsonville's broader commitment to reduce, reuse, and recycle, aiming to minimize its environmental footprint.

Their commitment to creating high-quality clothing while being environmentally conscious showcases their dedication to contributing to a more sustainable world.

Nissin Cup Noodles

 82 51

Environmental protection

Nissin Cup Noodles, through its EARTH FOOD CHALLENGE 2030 initiative, is actively working towards reducing its environmental impact with a focus on addressing climate change and limited resources. The company has set ambitious targets to source sustainably, conserve natural resources, and create a world without waste. They aim to achieve 100% sustainable palm oil procurement, reduce overall water use to 12.3 cubic meters per million yen of sales, and achieve a waste recycling ratio of 99.5% while reducing total waste by 50% compared to fiscal 2016. Additionally, Nissin is committed to reducing Scope 1+2 CO2 emissions by 42% and Scope 3 emissions by 25% compared to 2020 levels. They are also focusing on increasing the use of renewable energy in manufacturing processes and have introduced Biomass ECO Cups for their Cup Noodles brand, significantly reducing the use of petroleum-based plastic and CO2 emissions throughout the product's life cycle. In the US, Nissin has installed solar panels at their headquarters in Gardena, CA, allowing it to be powered by 100% renewable energy, and has implemented plant-wide energy reduction initiatives that successfully reduced CO2 emissions by 7% in FY22 compared to FY21.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nissin is exploring sustainable food sources by developing plant-derived meat alternatives and cultured meat. The company's Global Innovation Research Center has developed "Soy Meat" as a low environmental impact alternative to livestock-derived ingredients. Additionally, Nissin has achieved a world-first by successfully producing bovine muscle tissue in the form of diced steak through cell culture, highlighting their commitment to reducing the environmental impact of food production and potentially minimizing animal suffering in the future.

sources: 1

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Achieve 100% sustainable palm oil procurement
    • Reduce overall water use to 12.3 cubic meters per million yen of sales
    • Achieve a waste recycling ratio of 99.5% and reduce total waste by 50% compared to fiscal 2016
    • Reduce Scope 1+2 CO2 emissions by 42% and Scope 3 emissions by 25% compared to 2020 levels
    • Power the Gardena, CA headquarters with 100% renewable energy
    • Reduce CO2 emissions by 7% in FY22 compared to FY21 at the Gardena plant

Radisson

 82 48

Environmental protection

Radisson Hotel Group is actively engaged in various environmental protection initiatives aimed at reducing its carbon, energy, water, and waste footprint. The company is committed to science-based net zero by 2050 and is focused on finding energy-efficient solutions and increasingly using renewable energy sources. Radisson Hotel Group aims to reduce its carbon footprint by implementing renewable electricity solutions and has set a goal to increase the amount of renewable electricity it purchases and produces. Additionally, the group automatically offsets the carbon footprint of every meeting and event at its hotels worldwide, in partnership with First Climate, supporting projects that combat climate change and have a positive sustainable development contribution. Water stewardship is also a priority, with efforts to limit water use through technology improvements and the use of rainwater and gray water wherever possible. Radisson Hotel Group works to reduce, reuse, replace, and recycle, including food waste management and the elimination of single-use plastics. The company values third-party certification of its hotels' sustainability efforts through partnerships with global ecolabels like Green Key and EarthCheck.

Wyndham Hotels & Resorts

 82 51

Environmental protection

Wyndham Hotels & Resorts is actively engaged in environmental protection and sustainability efforts through its Wyndham Green Program. This program is designed to help hotels within the Wyndham network reduce their environmental footprints and operate more efficiently. The program encompasses a certification system with five progressive levels focusing on various sustainability elements such as energy and water conservation, waste diversion, operational efficiency, and the education and engagement of guests and employees. Specific initiatives include towel and linen reuse, interior and exterior energy-efficient lighting, recycling programs, water-efficient fixtures, eco-friendly cleaning products, energy-efficient laundry equipment, donation programs to reduce waste, paperless checkout, and single-use plastic minimization programs. Additionally, Wyndham is committed to climate change mitigation by reducing emissions, increasing the use of renewable energy, supporting waste diversion initiatives, conserving water, and protecting biodiversity. The company has also identified hotels within its portfolio that are located near key biodiversity or protected areas and is taking steps to mitigate potential impacts. Wyndham Hotels & Resorts is a member of the Sustainable Hospitality Alliance, collaborating with other hotel companies to reduce the environmental impact of the hospitality industry globally. The company's corporate headquarters in Parsippany, NJ, boasts Gold LEED EBOM and Energy Star Certification, further demonstrating its commitment to sustainability.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Wyndham Hotels & Resorts integrates diversity and inclusion into its business practices, viewing it as a competitive advantage. The company's inclusive culture reflects the diversity of its customers and communities worldwide. Additionally, Wyndham is committed to protecting human rights, with a specific focus on combating human trafficking. The company supports the UN Universal Declaration of Human Rights and collaborates with organizations such as BEST (Businesses Ending Slavery & Trafficking), ECPAT, and the Polaris Project to address all forms of human trafficking. This commitment is part of Wyndham's broader social responsibility efforts, which also include environmental sustainability and community support initiatives.

sources: 2

    • Implementing water efficiency projects at managed hotels in water-stressed areas in 2023

Heath

 82 55

Environmental protection

Heath Ceramics has implemented several initiatives to protect the environment, focusing on waste reduction, energy and carbon emissions management, water conservation, and sustainable shipping and purchasing practices. The company has significantly reduced landfill waste by finding innovative end-uses for various waste streams, such as donating production overrun mixed tile boxes to arts non-profit organizations, recycling nitrile plastic gloves into plastic furniture, recycling fired clay waste into raw material for concrete, and composting unusable clay. In the fiscal year 2023, Heath recycled over 200,000 gloves and achieved an 86% waste diversion rate from the landfill.

Heath uses 100% renewable electricity in its factories, sourced from solar and wind, and has converted over 350 fixtures to LED light bulbs to reduce energy consumption. The company's kilns are heated using natural gas, and its clay body is designed to be fired at a lower temperature than typical ceramic tableware and tile products, reducing energy usage. Heath tracks its carbon footprint across scope 1, 2, and 3 emissions, with scope 3 emissions accounting for about half of its total carbon footprint due to its comprehensive manufacturing process.

Water conservation efforts include the installation of water recycling systems at its Sausalito and San Francisco factories, which collect water from manufacturing for reuse. As of the fiscal year 2023, 55% of Heath's annual water intake is from internally recycled water. Additionally, the San Francisco Tile Factory and Retail Showroom feature permeable pavers and planter beds made from recycled Heath Tile and Dinnerware to divert water into the watershed rather than the drainage system.

For shipping, Heath uses ExpandOSâ¢, a biodegradable and recyclable paperboard pyramid, to replace foam packing peanuts and stabilize products. Dinnerware and Heath Home shipments are sent using UPS carbon-neutral shipping. The company also prioritizes sustainable purchasing practices, sourcing nearly half of its clay minerals locally and phasing out white clay from its formula to reduce the clay material footprint by 54%.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Heath Ceramics demonstrates a strong commitment to worker welfare through various initiatives, including equitable compensation, benefits, ergonomic support, and community engagement. The company offers retirement and healthcare benefits to all full-time employees and has developed a Living Wage Initiative in collaboration with ICA Fund in 2020, which expanded benefits and increased hourly wages. Starting wages are $25 an hour in the San Francisco Bay Area and $21.50 in Los Angeles. Employees also receive a minimum of eleven paid time-off days, nine paid holidays, and a paid volunteer day.

In 2016, Heath introduced the Employee Stock Ownership Plan, giving employees partial ownership of the company and increased retirement benefits through stock ownership. The company also focuses on workplace health and safety by providing weekly, in-person, onsite ergonomics training sessions and ergonomic assessments and equipment as needed.

Heath supports a diverse workforce by offering translation services, meetings in Spanish, and human resources personnel who can translate. The company reimburses employees for necessary work-related items, such as boots, headphones, and home office furniture.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • B Corp
    • California Green Business Certification
  • Commitments
    • Nothing found

Malibu Rum

 82 51

Environmental protection

Malibu Rum is actively engaged in environmental protection efforts, focusing on sustainable packaging and waste reduction. The company has made strides in incorporating recycled materials into its product packaging. Currently, 25% of the plastics used in Malibu bottles come from recycled sources. Additionally, the glass bottles are designed to be lightweight and are manufactured with approximately 30% recycled glass. Malibu has set a significant environmental commitment, aiming that by 2025, 100% of its bottles will be recyclable. This initiative is part of a broader effort to encourage consumers to recycle, emphasizing the impact of simple actions on long-term environmental sustainability. Through these measures, Malibu demonstrates a commitment to reducing its environmental footprint and promoting a culture of recycling among its consumers.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

Malibu Rum is committed to improving the livelihoods of coconut farmers in the Philippines, a key sourcing region for the coconuts used in their products. The company has pledged to positively impact the lives of 500 coconut farmers by 2025, aiming to increase their income by an average of 15% and their annual farm yield by 20%. This initiative is supported by partnerships with local coconut processor Franklin Baker, flavor producer Symrise, and GIZ, a global service provider in international cooperation for sustainable development and education. Through these collaborations, Malibu provides education and training to the farmers, focusing on sustainable farming practices guided by the Farm Sustainability Assessment (FSA) tool developed by the Sustainable Agriculture Initiative (SAI) Platform. These efforts are designed to address inefficiencies in farming practices, improve yields and income, and ensure the long-term sustainability of the coconut farming communities in the Philippines.

sources: 1, 2

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications

    • Nothing found

  • Commitments

    • By 2025, 100% of Malibu bottles will be recyclable.
    • By 2025, positively impact the livelihood of 500 coconut farmers by increasing their income by 15% (on average) and increasing annual farm yield by 20% (on average).
    • Help up to 75% of these farmers adapt their farming practices, guided by the Farm Sustainability Assessment (FSA) tool.

Duluth Trading Co.

 81 51

Environmental protection

Duluth Trading Co. is actively engaged in efforts to reduce its environmental impact and improve the earth's future. The company has adopted a philosophy against creating throwaway products, aiming to extend the life of its merchandise and thereby reduce waste. This approach not only benefits consumers by providing more durable products but also lessens the amount of waste that ends up in landfills. Duluth Trading Co. promotes product circularity, particularly in its outlet stores, by finding ways to increase product circulation and divert gently used returns from landfills. In terms of packaging, the company ensures that all consumer-facing outbound corrugate is recyclable and contains at least 79% recycled material. In 2022, Duluth Trading Co. recycled over 2,000 tons of material in its retail stores and fulfillment centers. Additionally, the company is committed to increasing the use of recycled materials in its products without compromising on quality or durability, demonstrating its ongoing commitment to eco-friendly practices.

The Vitamin Shoppe

 81 45

Environmental protection

The Vitamin Shoppe has implemented several initiatives aimed at protecting the environment. These include recycling initiatives, waste reduction efforts, and measures to lower their carbon footprint across their stores, distribution centers, and corporate headquarters. Notably, they sell reusable bags in their stores, encourage the use of email transaction receipts, repurpose in-store signage, operate single-stream recycling in many stores, and use environmentally friendly cleaning supplies. In their distribution centers, they have installed motion sensor lighting to reduce energy usage and recycle plastic and corrugate. Additionally, their store in Manahawkin, NJ, has achieved Gold LEED Certification, reflecting their commitment to sustainable design and construction practices in their new stores.

sources: 1

The Vitamin Shoppe emphasizes diversity and inclusion within its workforce, recognizing the importance of supporting communities across America with diverse and unique backgrounds. They are committed to combating discrimination and prejudice, especially against communities of color that continue to face historic injustices. The company pledges to bring different viewpoints together to uphold their commitment to wellness for all, indicating a holistic approach to wellness that includes body, mind, spirit, justice, fairness, and integrity.

Crate & Barrel

 81 47

Environmental protection

Crate & Barrel is actively engaged in various environmental protection initiatives aimed at reducing its carbon footprint and promoting sustainability. The company has committed to using more sustainably sourced materials in its products, including FSCÂ®-certified wood and preferred fibers, as well as recycled packaging. A significant step towards sustainability is their partnership with the Forest Stewardship CouncilÂ® (FSC) since 2008, aiming to achieve 50% FSC-certified furniture by 2025. Additionally, Crate & Barrel has made strides in reducing the environmental impact of its operations, as evidenced by the Green Building Initiative's Three Green Globes Certification awarded to their Romeoville, Illinois, distribution center and the installation of 100,000 square feet of solar panels at their Tracy location in California. The company also focuses on producing eco-friendly upholstery, with more than 50 styles now certified sustainable. This includes minimizing petroleum-based foam in cushions, using soy and corn-based alternatives, and incorporating recycled steel in furniture suspension systems. These efforts are part of Crate & Barrel's broader commitment to responsible design and environmental stewardship, without passing additional costs to customers.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Crate & Barrel demonstrates a commitment to worker welfare through various initiatives. The company has adopted the amfori BSCI code of conduct, which encompasses principles ranging from fair wages to health, safety, and environmental protections. They conduct social audits to ensure vendor compliance with this code of conduct and engage suppliers in continuous social and environmental improvement. Additionally, Crate & Barrel has a history of promoting diversity, equity, and inclusion within its leadership and workforce, with over 60% of CBH and store leaders identifying as female in 2021. The company also supports LGBTQ+ inclusion and has committed to increasing Black-owned business representation in its products by taking the 15% Pledge. Furthermore, Crate & Barrel has invested in long-term partnerships with U.S. upholsterers and manufacturers, supporting local craft communities and ensuring ethical production practices.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

    • FSCÂ® Certified

    • GREENGUARD Gold Certified

    • Grow GREENGUARD Gold Certified Crate & Kids furniture to 100% by 2025
    • Increase use of organic, recycled, and responsible materials to 60% certified preferred fibers by 2025

Bowflex

 81 38

Environmental protection

BowFlex Inc. has initiated several environmental protection efforts as part of its Environmental, Social, and Governance (ESG) program. The company conducted its first ESG assessment in 2021, which laid the foundation for establishing solid programs and synergies throughout the organization and its supply chain. A significant focus has been placed on recycling and reclamation, as well as improving utility usage. These initiatives are part of BowFlex Inc.'s broader commitment to continuously improve its ESG program in the coming years. The company also conducts ESG Supplier Assessments and Audits covering 95% of its supplier base, aiming to enhance transparency and improve its overall ESG program based on ISS and SASB documents, as well as stakeholder guidance.

sources: 1

Worker welfare

BowFlex Inc. is committed to improving worker welfare through various initiatives. The company's FY23 priorities for its ESG program include eliminating child labor and improving workplace safety. Additionally, BowFlex Inc. focuses on enhancing employee well-being and has established Employee Resource Groups (ERGs) to support diversity. These ERGs include Military Veterans & Allies, IDEA (Inclusion, Diversity, Equity, Awareness), and WILA (Women in Leadership & Allies), which foster collaboration and support among employees. Furthermore, BowFlex Inc. offers a paid benefit for U.S. employees to volunteer, with 124 employees volunteering a total of 932 hours in the FY23 fiscal year to support organizations in their community.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Nothing found

Caramello

Straight Talk Wireless

Norwegian Cruise Lines

 81 42

Environmental protection

Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings is actively engaged in various environmental protection efforts as part of its global sustainability program, Sail & Sustain. The company has set ambitious targets to reduce greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions, aiming for a 10% reduction by 2026 and a 25% reduction by 2030, compared to a 2019 baseline. These targets encompass emissions from its fleet of ships, islands, and facilities, as well as upstream fuel- and energy-related activities. Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings is also preparing for the future by modifying its final two Prima Class ships to accommodate green methanol as an alternative fuel source, highlighting its commitment to decarbonization. The company has successfully tested biodiesel blends in four of its ships and plans to expand this initiative. Additionally, it is investing in shore power capabilities, with a goal for approximately 70% of its fleet to be equipped with this technology by the end of 2025. Efforts to reduce single-use plastics have led to the elimination of over 20 million single-use plastic water bottles and 57 million plastic straws. The company also focuses on water stewardship, producing 90% of the fresh water used onboard its ships.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings places a strong emphasis on worker welfare, with a variety of initiatives aimed at supporting and empowering its employees. The company boasts a diverse global shoreside workforce, with 61% female team members, including 47% in managerial positions and above. In the U.S., 67% of shoreside team members are under-represented minorities, including 54% in managerial roles and above. In 2023, the company appointed three new brand Presidents, all of whom were internal and ethnically or gender diverse candidates. Norwegian Cruise Line Holdings also invests in training and development, with team members logging over 800,000 hours of training across various roles. The company supports its employees through student loan repayment and tuition reimbursement programs, contributing more than $500,000 in 2022. Additionally, it has expanded its suite of employee benefits to include fully paid maternity, paternity, and adoption leave, as well as family planning assistance for full-time U.S shoreside team members.

sources: 1

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Committing to a 10% reduction in GHG intensity by 2026 and a 25% reduction by 2030, compared to a 2019 baseline.
    • Targeting for ~50% of the fleet to be equipped with shore power technology by year-end 2024 and ~70% by year-end 2025.
    • Pursuing net zero GHG emissions by 2050 across operations and value chain.

Perdue

 81 50

Environmental protection

Perdue Farms has demonstrated a strong commitment to environmental stewardship through various initiatives aimed at reducing their carbon footprint, conserving natural resources, and promoting sustainability. They have installed solar panels at their LEEDÂ® Platinum-certified corporate offices and a feed mill, which is surrounded by a pollinator habitat, showcasing their dedication to renewable energy and biodiversity. The company has also engaged in significant recycling efforts, diverting over 70 million pounds of nitrogen and 46 million pounds of phosphorus from poultry litter out of the Chesapeake Bay watershed. Their methane extraction project in Cromwell, Kentucky, which converts methane from an anaerobic lagoon into electricity, has reduced CO2 emissions by approximately 100,000 tons. Additionally, Perdue's Project Clean Stream has removed over half a million pounds of trash from various waterways, and their support for oyster recovery in the Chesapeake Bay has contributed to the planting of nearly 25 million young oysters. These efforts are part of Perdue's broader environmental goals, which include aggressive reductions in greenhouse gases, water use, and solid waste by 2022, with a commitment to transparent reporting on their progress. Furthermore, their partnership with GreenGasUSA aims to further reduce carbon emissions by capturing and converting methane to renewable natural gas (RNG), which has already resulted in a 17% reduction in companywide carbon emissions. Perdue's collaboration with Bayer and ZeaKal focuses on reducing carbon emissions and increasing sustainability in the food value chain through regenerative farming practices and improved soy genetics, respectively. Lastly, their Indiana turkey facility has achieved GreenCircle Zero Waste to Landfill certification, marking a significant milestone in waste diversion and minimization efforts.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • LEEDÂ® Platinum Building Certification
    • GreenCircle Zero Waste to Landfill Certification
    • Audubon Bird-Friendly Habitat Certification
  • Commitments
    • Reduce greenhouse gas intensity by 30 percent by 2023
    • Reduce water usage intensity by 25 percent by 2023
    • Decrease solid waste to landfills by 90 percent by 2023

Skyy

 81 42

Environmental protection

SKYY Vodka has initiated a multi-year partnership with The Ocean Foundation (TOF), focusing on water conservation and the restoration of the planet's waterways. This collaboration is aimed at driving awareness, education, and action towards conserving and restoring the world's oceans. As part of this partnership, SKYY Vodka is contributing to the "For the Blue Fund" created with The Ocean Foundation. Additionally, SKYY Vodka is organizing beach cleanups, educational workshops, and events across the country to further conservation efforts. This initiative reflects both organizations' commitment to environmental conservation and sustainability, with a specific focus on ocean health. The Ocean Foundation, with its 20-year history, has directed over $84 million towards ocean conservation and restoration, emphasizing the importance of corporate partnerships like that with SKYY Vodka in making a significant impact on ocean health.

sources: 1

Dolce & Gabbana

 81 46

Environmental protection

Dolce & Gabbana is actively working towards a more sustainable and environmentally conscious fashion industry. The company has outlined seven priorities in its new Sustainability Plan, which include Net Zero Carbon, Zero Waste, Ecosystem Collaboration, Materials & Circularity, and Transparency & Traceability. These priorities aim to reduce the carbon footprint, transition to 100% renewable electricity, and implement a waste and resource recovery program. Additionally, Dolce & Gabbana has joined the Re.Crea Consortium, a project coordinated by the National Chamber of Italian Fashion, to manage end-of-life textile and fashion products and promote innovative recycling solutions. The company's efforts towards sustainability have been recognized with an award at the CNMI Sustainable Fashion Awards 2023.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Dolce & Gabbana is committed to promoting "Made in Italy" culture and tradition by involving the new generation in an ongoing dialogue between land and community. This commitment is part of their broader sustainability goals, which include Human Care & New Generations. The company aims to train young talents in the manufacturing sector, thereby safeguarding the territory and fostering a spirit of networking within the fashion industrial ecosystem. This approach not only ensures the preservation of craftsmanship and heritage but also supports the welfare of workers by providing opportunities for skill development and employment.

sources: 1, 2

Animal welfare

Nothing found

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Net Zero Carbon
    • Zero Waste
    • 100% renewable electricity

Goldman Sachs

 81 35

Environmental protection

Goldman Sachs is actively engaged in environmental protection through its commitment to sustainable finance, aiming to deploy $750 billion across investing, financing, and advisory activities by 2030 to accelerate climate transition and advance inclusive growth. The firm's approach to sustainability emphasizes two main themes: climate transition and inclusive growth, with a focus on clean energy, sustainable transport, sustainable food & agriculture, waste & materials, and ecosystem services. Goldman Sachs has made significant strides in clean energy financings and investments, with $115 billion allocated since 2006, and has underwritten $59 billion in green, social, and sustainability bonds since 2014. The firm also established an Environmental Policy Framework in 2005, acknowledging the importance of a healthy environment and committing to addressing critical environmental issues. This framework has guided the firm's commitment to the environment across its businesses, including the management of environmental and social risks with the same care as any other business risk. Additionally, Goldman Sachs is minimizing its operational impact as part of its environmental policy, demonstrating a comprehensive approach to sustainability that spans its investment practices and operational activities.

sources: 1, 2, 3

Worker welfare

Goldman Sachs is contributing to worker welfare through its community engagement initiatives, particularly the 10,000 Small Businesses and 10,000 Women programs. These programs are designed to help entrepreneurs create jobs and economic opportunity by providing access to education, capital, and business support services. The 10,000 Small Businesses initiative is an investment to help entrepreneurs grow their businesses and create jobs by offering access to education, capital, and support services. Similarly, the 10,000 Women program is a global initiative that fosters economic growth by providing women entrepreneurs around the world with a business and management education, mentoring and networking, and access to capital. These initiatives demonstrate Goldman Sachs' commitment to advancing inclusive growth and supporting underserved populations, leveraging the firm's capabilities to improve access and affordability in education and community development.

sources: 1, 2

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • Nothing found
  • Commitments
    • Deploying $750 billion across investing, financing, and advisory activities by 2030 to accelerate climate transition and advance inclusive growth

Princess Cruises

 81 37

Environmental protection

Princess Cruises has demonstrated a commitment to environmental protection through various initiatives aimed at preserving the marine environment and minimizing air pollution. The company has invested in state-of-the-art technology to prevent pollution, including the pioneering use of shore power technology that allows ships to "plug in" and use shore-based electricity, reducing emissions while docked in ports such as Juneau, Alaska; Seattle, Washington; and San Francisco, Los Angeles, San Diego, CA; New York, and Halifax Nova Scotia. Additionally, Princess Cruises is implementing Advanced Air Quality Systems (AAQS) to meet low sulfur fuel requirements more cost-effectively, with 14 ships expected to have EGCS installations by 2020. The company also focuses on water use and waste water treatment, employing systems to treat gray and black water before discharge and encouraging water conservation among guests and crew. Solid waste management practices include minimizing plastic use, recycling, and proper disposal of food waste in compliance with environmental laws. Princess Cruises has also taken steps to manage hazardous waste responsibly and prevent oil pollution, highlighting their comprehensive approach to environmental stewardship.

sources: 1, 2

Worker welfare

Nothing found

Animal welfare

Nothing found

Transparency

  • Certifications
    • ISO 14001 Environmental Management System
  • Commitments
    • Installation of shore power technology on 16 vessels by 2020
    • Installation of Advanced Air Quality Systems (EGCS) on 14 ships by 2020
    • 80% of the fleet to have advanced water treatment systems by 2020

As a public benefit corporation (PBC), Scope emphasizes its commitment to prioritizing the planet in its operations.
